Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH.

Re: Water Supply and Pressure Tank,
St. Paul's Indian Residential School,
Cardston, Alberta.

We have had considerable trouble with the water at the St. Paul's School within the last few months and while we think we have the matter under control at the present time, we have received a letter from Indian Superintendent Ragan which reads, in part, as follows:

"To add to our troubles on the water system at this school, the Provincial Boiler Inspector, Mr. W. A. Henry visited us to inspect pressure vessels. He found that the large water pressure tank installed by the Surveys and Engineering Branch of the Department at Banff early in 1947 was buried deep in the ground and he could not inspect same. He stated that this was a pressure vessel carrying 80 lbs. pressure and has been installed contrary to all the laws and regulations regarding high pressure vessels, that it had to be inspected once each year and must be set on concrete trunnions in a concrete pit so that it could be inspected. This is the tank we had trouble with last September when it sank further in the clay soil shearing off the connecting pipes.

"The new well, of course, had to be drilled outside the existing building and is now sitting out in the open without protection of any kind. A building will have to be..."
erected over this and as it is near the pressure vessel, and if Mr. Henry is correct, one structure can be built to house both the pump and the pressure tank. Excavation and cement work would have to be done around the tank, and I would suggest that the building be constructed of cinder blocks and frame and shingle roof, approximately 24 x 30 feet. I am quite aware that this school has had their full share, and more, of improvements this fiscal year, but I see no alternative but to erect this building. If you concur in this I shall procure tenders and costs."

In connection with the above, I would refer you to memorandum from your Branch dated October 29, 1947, and previous correspondence.

The last paragraph of your memorandum of October 29 read as follows:

"It would seem quite likely to us that it was the air pipe and not the tank that settled, as the tank should have been placed on solid ground and, of course the air pipe would be placed through the unconsolidated fill material and the extra weight of water from the roof might have possibly sheared off a weak thread at the tank. The installation now appears to be working satisfactorily."

The information given by our Superintendent appears to be different from the information quoted from your memorandum.

We would appreciate it if you would have one of your officials visit the St. Paul's School at the earliest possible date and report on the suggestion of Superintendent Ragan that a building be erected to house both the pump and the pressure tank.

Director
Ottawa, June 22, 1948.

Classroom Blocks - Blood R.C. Indian Residential School
St. Paul's C.E. Indian Residential School.

Reference your 103-10-8 of June 10 -

Included in our supplementary estimates for 1948/49 is the sum of $12,000.00 for the moving and setting up of these classroom blocks. We have already approved a tender from A. Kaughman & Sons amounting to $6,500.00 for the moving of these two buildings. This leaves an amount of $5,500.00.

Major Clark has specifically recommended the installation of full basements under these buildings and the Department concurs in his recommendation. The lowest tender for the installation of these basements is that of H. Weston and it amounts to $6,640 (broken down into two separate bids of $2,739 and $3,901). This means that an additional amount is required over and above our estimates of $1,440 and will necessitate a transfer of funds in this amount.

Before proceeding with such a transfer it is essential that we know what additional funds will be required for:

(a) Stair wells,
(b) Posts and/or pillars for bracing,
(c) Laying of drain and water pipe,
(d) Installation of electrical wiring.
Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA, Ont.

Classroom Blocks - Blood Reserve Schools
Your Files: 103-2-5 and 103-1-5

After much difficulty and travel we are now able to enclose herewith competitive tenders on foundations on basements needed at the proposed sites of our new classroom blocks.

We would recommend, if at all possible, that full basements be put under these buildings and we have had each contractor tender on the full basement as well as surface foundation so that comparisons may be made. The advantages of full basements was discussed with Major Clark while he was on the Blood Reserve.

Contractors were asked to tender on full basements with 8" walls, 8' high, 4" floor with footings and installing ten windows and frames. Stairwells have not been included, nor has any posts or pillars for bracing; drains and laying of water pipe and electrical wiring will also be extra.

Following is a comparison of the tenders as submitted:

|                | R. Weston | T. Weston | D. Watson |
|----------------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| Full Basement - St. Paul's - | $2759.00 | $2740.00 | $3000.00 |
| Surface Foundation - St. Paul's - | 496.00 | 659.00 | 735.00 |
| Full Basement - R. C. School - | 3901.00 | 5040.00 | 4442.00 |
| Surface Foundation - R. C. School - | 1268.00 | 1333.00 | 950.00 |

Each contractor has stated that he would be glad to do the work on a cost plus 10% basis, with the Department furnishing all material.

A. Kaughman and Sons now have both buildings ready to truck to sites, but are held up on account of the swollen condition of the river. This condition in all probability, will not get back to normal for another month yet.

It is hoped that one contractor can be given the entire work, and that authority to proceed can be given at an early date.

Yours truly,

(R. D. Ragam)
Superintendent.

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Reference your letter 103-1-5 (E.l) of June 4th regarding the erection of a building for the Farm Instructor at St. Paul's Residential School, Blood Reserve.

Please be advised that tentative arrangements have been made with the Principal of St. Paul's school to move a small Indian residence which they have purchased on to the school grounds for use by the farm instructor.

In view of this, we suggest that the money be held for things which are more vitally needed at this school, and we also suggest that this matter be held in abeyance at this time.

As you know, the roof of this school has just been re-shingled, and it is important that it be covered with some kind of wood preserver before the new shingles curl and damage. It will be my suggestion that money be allotted for this roof instead of the farm instructor residence. I am enclosing some literature on the wood preserver which is sold in Cardston and seems to me to be what we would want. The price of this wood preserver is $1.79 per gallon less 5% and we would need approximately 200 gallons to give the St. Paul's roof the coating, amounting to $340.10 for the preserver. Mr. S.D. Wolff of Cardston has agreed to supply this material on the roof for the sum of $300.00 making a total expense for the job $640.10.

If the Department are in agreement, may a purchase order be issued to Mr. R. H. Crawford, Cardston, Alta., for 200 gallons wood preserver, and may Mr. Woolf offer to paint this roof for $300.00 be accepted.

(R.D. Kagan)
Superintendent

Refrigeration
St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School, Cardston, Alta.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Refrigeration
St. Paul's Anglican Indian
Residential School, Cardston, Alberta.

Thank you for your letter 103-1-5 (E-1) of 22nd July, 1948, stating that the matter of provision of refrigeration will have your careful consideration when you hear from your Superintendent.

I note what you say regarding the heavy expenditure you have incurred at this school during the current year on renewal of the roof, but I would be glad if you keep in mind when you are considering your Superintendent's report that this school now has no refrigeration facilities of any kind. In such circumstances, the preservation for even a reasonable time of the produce of the school farm, such as meat, milk, etc., is practically impossible, to say nothing of the additional cost involved through the necessity of purchasing other perishable foodstuffs in small quantities for day to day consumption.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook.
Superintendent.

Archdeacon S.H. Middleton, Principal, St. Paul's Anglican School on the Blood Reserve has handed me the attached correspondence regarding a walk-in refrigerator.

St. Paul's Residential School,

Dear Archdeacon Middleton,

Re: Refrigeration.

In one of the letters General Turner has sent into the office he emphasized your school's need for adequate refrigeration.

Yesterday morning I was able to sell the idea to the Indian Affairs Branch and I am quite sure that they are now prepared to install the refrigeration unit at your school. However, they do require full details as to the adequate cubic contents of such a refrigerator and whether or not a walk-in refrigerator would be of service. May I suggest that you, in cooperation with the Agent, go into this matter fully and both submit your recommendations to your principals.

Yours faithfully,

Sgd."Henry G. Cook"
Superintendent.
Venerable Archdeacon S.H. Middleton,
St. Paul's Anglican Indian School,
Cardston, Alta.

Dear Sir;

Further to the inquiry re refrigeration for the St. Paul's School, and also further to my visit and conversation with Mr. Charles Middleton, please be advised of the following quotations in respect to the reach-in cabinet for the kitchen, and the walk-in cooler for storage.

Your reach-in cabinet in the kitchen can be built to any size required up to the following dimensions. That is the actual size of the compartment you will store food in. The size could be 3 ft. in width, 4 ft. in height, and 7 ft. in length inside box measurements. This cabinet should be so constructed that you have at least 3 inches of insulation all around. The doors will also have to be insulated and have rubber stripping around the outside edge so that they will fit tightly against the face of the box proper. The insulation would be of rock wool and comes in five cubic feet per bag.

The price of the condensing unit complete with a fin coil and drip trays, the necessary refrigeration controls and tubing, the electrical installation and refrigeration installation would be $412.50. The above price does not include the cost of the rock wool insulation or the necessary door hinges and door latches. The rock wool insulation would cost you a $1.85 per 5 cubic feet bag F.O.B. Calgary, and the door latch and hinges would be approximately $8.00 per set.

In respect to the walk-in cooler, I suggested to Mr. Charles Middleton that you would build an anti-room adjacent to the walk-in cooler where we could install a fin coil for cooling the beef before it is hung in the freezer proper. It will also be necessary to have at least 8 inches of rock wool insulation laid on the concrete floor, and wood floor laid on top of that. Also the wall of the refrigerator proper and anti-room will also have to be insulated with rock wool. We can again supply the necessary rock wool for this purpose at $1.85 per 5 cubic feet bag, F.O.B. Calgary. In estimating the equipment that would be required for this walk-in refrigerator, we have estimated that you would be freezing 200 pounds of beef per day, and having a total storage of 3000 pounds. Therefore, the walk-in refrigerator will require a 1 H.P. condensing unit, dole plate, controls, etc., and we could install same complete with the necessary electrical installation and refrigeration, and also the fin coil required, installed in the anti-room, for the sum of $1,372.00.
The equipment that would be used in most installations would be the Universal Cooler Company of Canada Condensing Units, and also the highest grade of controls and other equipment that are necessary for us to install and give you the best of service in refrigeration for your reach-in cabinet in the kitchen and walk-in cooler for storage.

I would ask that you please give this your consideration and either notify Mr. John Woslyng of Cardston or ourselves of your decision in respect to the above equipment. Please be advised that we could install this equipment immediately, as we can give you delivery from our own stock and also another thought to keep in mind is that once our stock of equipment is sold from Calgary, any new equipment that we will have to bring from the factory will be a higher price as we now understand there has been an increase of 25% on all refrigeration equipment.

Hoping to receive a favourable reply, I remain,

Yours very truly,

ELECTRIC CRAFTS LIMITED

Sgd. "J. Fleming"

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
August 5, 1948.

Mr. R.D. Ragan, Supt. of Indian Agency, Cardston, Alta.,

We have your letter of the 21st ultimo with reference to the installation of a walk-in refrigerator at the St. Paul's Residential School.

Owing to the various improvements, the expenditure at this school has been rather heavy this year and at the moment we can not see our way clear to provide the funds that would be required if we accepted the proposal of Electric Crafts Limited.

However, you might prepare a more definite specification regarding exactly what is needed and submit same to us about the middle of October. We will then be in a position to decide the amount of funds still available in our appropriation and if the expenditure can be authorized we will do so then.

We have had some inquiries from the Secretary of the M.S.C.C., with reference to paint that is required. We have reviewed our file and we can not find any requisition that has been forwarded to us for payment.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum

Re: Water Supply and Pressure Tank
St. Paul's Indian Residential School
Cardston, Alberta

Referring to the memorandum from Indian Affairs dated June 22nd, 1948, we have now received a report from Mr. Cornish dated July 16th, duplicate copies of which are attached herewith.

You will note that the pressure tank is being operated at a maximum pressure of 50 pounds per square inch, so inspection by the Alberta Boiler Inspector is not apparently obligatory. As a pressure of only 25 pounds per square inch is available on the top floor of the school, fire protection there will not be as satisfactory as might be obtained if a higher pressure were maintained in the tank and in the pipes. Before the installation of the pressure tank last year the elevated outside gravity tank only provided 15 pounds per square inch pressure on the top floor, so under present conditions fire protection has been improved throughout the building.

It would seem advisable, however, to replace the weak pipes and fittings in the school whenever an opportunity occurs to do so, so that a more satisfactory fire pressure could be maintained.

Mr. Cornish suggests that the urgent work required consists of the erection of a house for the pump at a cost of $100.00, to be heated by a radiator at present on hand at the school. This house for the pump would be temporary only, and has been suggested in order to provide a cover for the pump and wall if the more permanent construction of a concrete wall for the pressure tank and a larger pumphouse with extra garage space for two cars cannot be built this year at a cost of $300.00 plus $900.00 = $1400.00. If only $100.00 can be provided this year the more permanent work, costing $1400.00, could be included in next year's estimates.

If the temporary work only is to be done this year it would appear that the local representative of Indian Affairs could handle the work of building the small 8 x 8 pump shelter, and any necessary instructions could be obtained by mail from Mr. G.H. Cornish, Inspecting Engineer, Department of Mines and Resources, Banff, Alberta.

Will you kindly advise what decision is reached by Indian Affairs in this matter.

Re: Pressure Tank,
St. Paul's Indian Residential School.

Following the instructions of your letter of June 26th, an inspection was made of the above installation on July 6th, 1948.

A sketch plan of the area containing the pressure tank and pump is attached. Also attached is a copy of an estimate received by Superintendent Ragan from a Cardston contractor quoting a price of $1286.00 for a building to house pressure tank and pump and also to provide garage space.

The pressure tank is buried under approximately three feet of earth cover and with the head some twelve feet outside the basement wall. The exact position of the tank was not ascertained. The change from the original intention of placing the head of the tank in the boiler room was explained in Mr. Snelson's memorandum of May 30th, 1947, from which I quote:

"The large tank was installed in the only location on the outside of the boiler room basement wall not occupied by coal bin, ash hoist or chimney foundations. In this location at a depth of six feet below ground surface, the 4" pipeline from the pump to the outside tank was uncovered. This line crossed the trench at such an angle that it was necessary to place the end of the tank at a distance of twelve feet from the outside boiler room wall so that the bottom of the tank could be set at an elevation of eight feet below ground surface. It was not advisable to cut the 4" pipe as it was at the time under pressure supplying water to the school."

At the time of my visit, the pressure tank was being operated at a pressure range between 40 and 50 p.s.i., the school authorities being doubtful of the strength of the old fixtures under higher pressure. Operation of the tank has been quite satisfactory since the air line was repaired. The present pressure range will only supply approximately 25 p.s.i., at the top floor of the school which is inadequate for fire streams.

I was unable to see Boiler Inspector.............

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Division,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.
I was unable to see Boiler Inspector Henry at Lethbridge but visited the Boiler Inspector's office at the Alberta Public Works in Calgary on July 9th. No one in that office could find any regulations governing the installation and inspection of pneumatic pressure tanks. However, I was informed that they usually inspected such tanks, with internal pressure exceeding 50 p.s.i., once every two years, and require access to outside and inside for inspection purposes. In order to obtain further information on this point, I visited the office of the Resident Architect, Dominion Public Works Department, and was unable to find any regulations covering installation of pneumatic pressure tanks. The Boiler Inspector for the Dominion Public Works is stationed in Victoria, B.C. I might add that I acquired a copy of the Alberta Rollers Act and Regulations and have perused them without finding any regulations re installation, access or inspection of such tanks.

It appears fairly evident that the existing installation transgresses no regulations if the upper range of operation is kept at 50 p.s.i., nor does it constitute a source of danger to the school population. However, it does not appear to be good practice to install a pressure tank without means of access for inspection and since we have to depend on Alberta Government inspection, a tank should be installed according to their requirements. Consequently I would recommend that the existing tank be placed in a concrete lined excavation and set on concrete trunnions to raise it above the floor.

The proper method of housing the tank would be to insert the head through the basement wall as originally planned and obtain access to the containing pit by way of the basement. It would be necessary to place a fairly heavy beam lintel over the opening cut out for the tank as a large window opening occurs above as shown on the sketch. Heating for the tank pit would hardly be necessary; if it proves necessary, steam and radiation are available. It is estimated that the tank housing as indicated by red lines on the sketch would cost approximately $600.00.

Under the circumstances there seems to be no great necessity for building this housing immediately, and if funds are short it could be estimated for from next year's appropriation. Any work in connection with the tank should be done during the summer vacation period.

There appears to be no need for the large garage building indicated in the contractor's drawings. No good purpose seems to be served by trying to combine this building with the tank housing. The large building would require demolition of the present work shop and probably necessitate its replacement later.

It is recommended that a building approximately 22' x 24' with a roof pitching from 8 feet to 6 feet be erected if funds are available. This would house the pump, provide storage for two cars, allow retention of the work shop and also prevent blocking light from the basement window. School authorities state that radiators are available and steam supply ample for heating the addition. It is estimated that a structure as indicated would cost approximately $800.00.

If the above funds are not...........................
If the above funds are not available, the essential item at this time is heated housing for the pump. A shelter 8 feet by 8 feet with a wood flooring and steam radiator would probably cost $100.00 but could not be used as part of a future garage building.

The contractor's bid for his suggested plan of garage etc., appears to be very reasonable, and he should be asked to bid on the revised plans.

Inspecting Engineer.

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA.

I have your letters, file 103-1-5 (E.I) of September 13th and 16th with reference to the pressure tank and garage, St. Paul's Residential School, Blood Reserve.

Referring to your letter of Sept. 13th (1) it was suggested that the pressure tank be excavated and the concrete placed around it, as the Boiler Inspector for the Province stated that this tank, being buried, violated all Provincial and Dominion regulations regarding pressure vessels, and that it would have to be excavated to allow periodic inspections. You will recall that Mr. C.R. Cornish, Inspecting Engineer of Lands and Developments Branch inspected this. His memorandum was quoted in your letter, even file of August 9th. He states in this memorandum, that inspection is not absolutely obligatory; however, your letter of the 15th states that pressure tanks must be placed so that they can be inspected from all surfaces. We certainly do not want to go to this extra expense, if the Department feels that inspection is not necessary, and it would be appreciated if we could get a definite ruling on this.

Regarding number 2, the building of a pump house and a separate building for car storage would entail more expense than the garage-pump house unit of which we forwarded plans. However, if the Department feels that because of the fire hazard, the two buildings should be constructed, we are certainly agreeable. The two car garage can be constructed at a very reasonable cost. It is the excavating and cementing in of the pressure tank which is costing the big money in this instance.

The only buildings that could be used for car storage at St. Paul's School, are sheds situated adjacent to the barns and the fire hazard here would be magnified many times. Separate heating units would have to be installed and I would not recommend this procedure. The Assistant Principal is leaving this School at the end of September, however, this will not alter the need of a two car garage as this School operates two cars.
Finally, our recommendations are:

(1) That if it is not necessary to excavate the pressure tank, that this be eliminated.

(2) That the combination two-car garage and pump house be built to attach to the brick school building.

We believe this to be the most economical and satisfactory from the standpoint of usefulness. We do not believe the danger of fire would be great and could eliminate this even more by building a concrete block garage. However, we will await the Department's wishes and recommendations regarding all this.

(R.D. Ragan)
Superintendent.

We received your letter of August 24th with reference to the class room blocks at the St. Paul's and Blood Schools.

It is noted that you are unable to obtain firm tenders from local contractors for plumbing, heating, etc.

In view of the contents of official letter of September 8th, we will wait for a reply to that letter before making any final decision.

In connection with the second paragraph of your letter regarding the passageways, our understanding is that if we finally decide to heat these class room blocks with hot air furnaces, passageways will not be necessary for carrying steam pipes.

It is possible that we have not explained fully to you the reasons why we do not favour the passageways. The provision of separate class room blocks at residential schools is a new policy which we have just adopted and one of the primary reasons for the action is that we felt that if the class rooms were set apart from the main building, it would have a tendency to improve conditions at the residential schools where the class room blocks were provided, as the pupils would be leaving the main building for periods each day to go to the class rooms.
It might be inferred from your letter that the management of the schools consider it unnecessary work to have the children dress to go to a separate building. We feel that this is in the best interests of the pupils and the school management as well.

If we finally decide to heat these buildings by hot air, it is presumed it will not be necessary to purchase the stoker for the St. Paul's School.

Mr. Snyder stated that his successors were not capable of figuring on such a plant, and that he would be required to do so for them. In fact, he would send a qualified engineer to make plans, from which he could figure the costs. The plan of heating would be based on the assumption that the buildings were properly insulated and that the heating of them would be supplied from the existing boilers of the main buildings.

He stated further that an escape clause in the contract might be required, as there is always a possibility of unforeseen increases in freight rates and material costs.

Mr. Snyder stated that to prepare these plans and submit a contract was costly. Naturally this firm was anxious to get the business, but he felt that there should be some assurance that the work would not be lost.

Mr. Snyder is well acquainted with the buildings that have been moved from the Airports, as he installed the heating plants when they were erected. He stressed that the buildings should be inspected for insulation, and, if the insulation as originally put into them has been impoverished or is missing, it must be replaced or replenished, as it would be impossible to heat them from the residential school plants. He stated that it would be preferable to have a passage-way between the blocks and the main buildings. However, a compressing pump must be set up at each school to carry the steam or hot water to distant points.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Regan, the Superintendent. I hope you can give him instructions that he may proceed with confidence that the contract will finally be approved.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Ottawa, November 1, 1948.

Re: St. Paul's C.E. Indian Residential School, St. Mary's R.C. Indian Residential School, Blood Reserve, Alberta.

You are advised that as a result of a verbal request from the Indian Affairs Branch, supported by a memorandum from Major MacKay, dated October 23rd, which bears your notation of the 26th instant; our heating engineer carried out an inspection on the 24th, 25th and 26th instances, to determine the best means of heating the new classroom blocks in connection with the above schools.

One "T" shape R.C.A.F. Link Trainer Building was moved from a nearby camp and set up on a previously prepared concrete foundation at St. Paul's C.E. School for use as a classroom block, and a walking passage has been constructed to join the two buildings.

One "H" shape R.C.A.F. Link Trainer Building was moved from the camp and set up on a previously prepared concrete foundation at St. Mary's R.C. School for use as a classroom block, and a walking passage between the two buildings is now under construction. All this work is being carried out under the direction of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Full size basements under each building have been completed and the design of the suitable heating system for each block in addition to the plumbing connections, is now being carried out by this Division.

It had been suggested by local authorities and the School Principals that a steam line from the residential school boiler plant in each school, be carried through the passage and connected to a heating system in the new classroom blocks. Upon investigating the boiler plants, it was found that there was no excess capacity in either plant to handle any additional load. The boiler plants in each of the above residential schools, are over 25 years old and it is estimated that they may continue to function for a period of approximately 5 to 10 years before replacement will be necessary.

The individual heating plants which originally served the R.C.A.F. blocks, are not suitable for re-use. They were designed to heat one floor only and with the addition of a full basement, their capacity is under that which is required. In addition, one boiler is fitted for gas firing and both units were designed for use with special hot blast heating equipment, including plenum chambers, fans, controls, etc., all of which, before assembly, would require extensive adjustments and would not be economically feasible or suitable for the present requirements. Some vital parts of this equipment were found to be missing.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
It is recommended that a separate forced hot water heating system be installed in each of the new classroom blocks; including square sectional cast iron hot water heating boilers, circulating pumps, radiation, piping and elementary controls. Such systems can be readily installed with the least amount of delay and expense.

At such time in the future when the residential school boiler plants are replaced, the new boilers can be selected with sufficient capacity to serve the residential school, the domestic hot water load for winter service, and the heating in the classroom blocks. The only change required in the classroom blocks, will be the addition of a steam fed convertor to replace the hot water heating boiler along with minor piping revisions in the boiler room. The hot water heating boiler can then be put to use in the residential schools to heat domestic hot water, as by that time, the present methods now inadequate, will be totally deficient.

The plumbing from each of the new blocks, will be connected into the existing services from the residential schools and full instructions were outlined to the general contractor on the job.

Acting on a verbal request from the Indian Affairs Branch which will be confirmed by a memorandum from Major MacKay, this Division is now preparing plans and specifications covering the heating and plumbing at both the above schools and when complete, they will be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch who have undertaken to award the contract and have the installations carried out under their direction.

Will you kindly pass this on for consideration. Christmas is almost here, and we have no lights for the Church?"

I understand that the M.S.C.C. are arranging for this work to be carried out and that they will probably request payment from this office for this amount. I advised them that I would have to wait for a report from you before any further action could be taken. However, we have set a precedent in a similar situation at another Residential School and the M.S.C.C., are aware of this other incident.

I have your letter of December 29th, file 764-5 (E) quoting a letter from Canon Cook of the M.S.C.C. regarding electrical service to the Anglican Church on the Blood Indian Reserve.

The electrical line to the Church at the St. Paul's School was in very bad shape, moving contractors took down some wire and no more than one or two posts; this could have been reconnected by the school engineer in less than half an hour.

Archdeacon Middleton came to me in December requesting that this line be entirely rebuilt. He was told that we could not do this - if it was to be rebuilt to the Church, it was a Church responsibility. He was told that his Engineer would have to reconnect the wires - a simple job. I was then told that all the wire was missing - as were the posts - where they went to I do not know. It was then learned that posts alone would cost over $100.00, and wire and labor = approximately $150.00. I advised Archdeacon Middleton to get in touch with M.S.C.C. authorities as I considered it their responsibility.

The M.S.C.C. responded with a telegram to buy the posts - but this was only half the job - who was going to buy the wire and who was going to pay labor? As it was near Christmas, I instructed the Modern Home Electric to furnish wire and labor so that electricity might be available for the holidays, and this was done. I assured Archdeacon Middleton that if his authorities would not pay for the lighting of his Church, I would ask the Department to do so. The Modern Home Electric have been instructed to submit their account to Archdeacon Middleton.

(R.D. Regan)

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

St. Paul's Residential School, Blood Reserve.

On August 3, 1948, we submitted to you a tender from R. Weston of Cardston, Alberta, for the installation of two full basements for the classroom buildings being moved to the St. Paul's Residential School and the Blood Residential School, on the Blood Indian Reserve. When Mr. Weston completed this work, the question was raised of joining the new classroom blocks with the main building, preparatory to the installation of the heating units required. Mr. Indian Superintendent Ragan was advised to have firm tenders obtained for the installation of this passageway. Unfortunately, the weather closed in and Mr. Ragan apparently permitted Mr. Weston to begin the construction of the connecting passage without the proper authority.

We have now received the attached account from Mr. Weston in the amount of $701.61 for the erection of this connecting tunnel. The work has been examined by the engineer who visited the school to prepare the plans and specifications for the heating units to be installed. He feels that this work has been well and efficiently done. If it had not been done by Mr. Weston, it would have been necessary to have this tunnel built in order to carry the water and sewage pipes. Mr. Ragan has been written to, concerning the issuing of authority for such contracts and we feel confident that there will not be a repetition of such matters. I would therefore recommend that you authorize the payment of this account.

Knoi.

Director.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 15 FEBRUARY 1949

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 7th February, 1949, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources is renovating two former Air Force buildings, one to provide a four-classroom school to be operated in connection with the St. Paul's Indian Residential School and the other to be operated in connection with the Blood Indian Residential School, both schools being located on the Blood Indian Reserve, in the Blood Indian Agency, in the Province of Alberta;

THAT the renovation of these buildings has reached the stage where plumbing and heating should be installed;

THAT in this connection, the following tenders have been received:

| Name                        | Amount of Tender |
|-----------------------------|------------------|
| Walker & Holberton, Lethbridge, Alberta, | $28,191.60       |
| H. Kelly & Company, Edmonton, Alberta,    | 25,000.00        |
| George H. Baxter & Son, Lethbridge, Alberta, | 22,200.00        |
| Snyder & Boon, Calgary, Alberta,          | 18,800.00        |
| Hall Brothers, Cardston, Alberta,         | 17,525.00        |

THAT the above tenders have been examined by Departmental Engineers and it is found that they comply with conditions outlined on tender forms prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and with the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

THAT the Departmental Engineers recommend the acceptance of the tender of Hall Brothers, of Cardston, Alberta, in an amount of $17,525.00;

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 218, 1948-49, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The Committee, therefore on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of Hall Brothers, of Cardston, Alberta, for the installation of plumbing and heating in both buildings, for the amount of $17,525.00.

The Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources.

Dear Colonel Neary:

On 15th October, 1947, we submitted to you a list of requirements at the above school for inclusion in your 1948-49 Estimates and this list contained, among others, an estimate of $1,803.10 for labour and materials for interior painting. In your letter 103-1-5 (W.T.L) of 23rd October, 1947, you advised us that this would be given careful consideration when your estimates for the fiscal year 1948-49 were being prepared.

In the anticipation that the above service would be carried out during the fiscal year 1948-49, we advised you on 28th August, 1948 (acknowledged by your 103-1-5 (E.1) of 21st September, 1948, that only $125.00 need be provided for interior painting in your 1949-50 estimates.

The Principal reports that nothing has been done in the matter of this interior painting and in describing the interior of the building he writes that "never since the School was built in 1924 has it been in such a poor state and run down condition. Every room presents a beggarly appearance."

It is understood that a contractor in Cardston submitted a tender for this interior painting to your Mr. Ragan early last summer.

It is appreciated that you have expended a considerable amount at this School during the current fiscal year on new roof, etc. (and in this connection it is pointed out that the old leaky roof contributed largely to the damage to the interior decoration) but as rooms badly in need of decoration are unattractive and depressing from the standpoint of staff, pupils and the public who may visit the school, it seems most desirable that the interior painting required be carried out as early as possible.

Will you please advise me what you plan on doing in this matter.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent

Re: St. Paul's Residential School,
Blood Indian Reserve.

Reference your letter of the 25th October, 1948, file 764-5 (E) regarding a combination garage-pump house to be built at the above school on the Blood Indian Reserve.

As you know this building was constructed but it was found that in the severe weather of the winter the building was so large that we could not get enough heat into it to properly protect the pumping unit. As a consequence, special protection regarding the covering of the unit etc. were employed.

To avoid danger of this pump freezing in the future, I have conferred with the contractor and we have agreed that the pumping unit should be closed off from the rest of the garage by a partition, the walls of which should be insulated. This small room should definitely be heated and all danger of frost eliminated.

Mr. T. Weston has given me his estimate to complete this work, which is attached, and which amounts to $108.17. To avoid a possible major expense later on, may authority be given to build this small partition enclosing the pump unit at this school.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LAND AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH,

Blood Indian Residential School,
St. Paul's Indian Residential School.

It is understood that a verbal request has been made for the sending of one of your Heating Engineers to visit these two schools which are situated some few miles apart in the Blood Indian Agency, Cardston, Alberta.

I appreciate the promptitude with which this request has been met. We have moved two Air Force buildings from nearby camps and have them now set up on full basement foundations at these schools. These buildings were former Link Trainer units and are already fitted up with classrooms. They will provide ideal classroom blocks at these two schools.

By converting the present classrooms into extra dormitories and by using the new classroom blocks, we will be able to provide accommodation for many more children at each of these schools. At present we are not providing any additional facilities whatsoever for over 100 children on this reserve.

Our Superintendent of Education found on his recent visit that the only serious problem now remaining before these classroom blocks can be opened is that of heating them. Our Regional Supervisor for Alberta and the local Indian Superintendent both made strong representations that a heating engineer should recommend the best way in which these buildings can be heated, in view of the magnitude of the tenders which will probably be involved.

Our field officials are agreed that the calling in of local heating contractors would not have solved the problem.

Sir,

In accordance with instructions received in your letter of the 28th inst., I visited the proposed site for the new school on Blood Indian Reserve, and beg to submit the following report on water supply.

Date of inspection: 19th May, 1913.

I understand it is two years since Mr. Ostrander left the Blood Indian Reserve and Mr. F. Faunt is now the agent.

I met Mr. Faunt and the Rev. Middleton, on the ground, and they pointed out the proposed site and the spring from which it is proposed to get a water supply. The school site is on the SW corner of the NW¼ sec. 24-3-16-4, and the spring is on the SE¼ of sec. 23-3-16-4, as shown on accompanying sketch.

The flow of the spring at date of inspection was at the rate of 1,400 gallons per day (24 hours), and it might be much less during a dry summer. This is the only nearby spring on the reserve. The spring is in a small creek bed and 100 feet below the spring the creek bed was dry.

I was informed that there might be sixty (60) head of stock at the school therefore the requirements for this alone, at 10 gallons per head, would be 1,200 gallons per day, leaving only 200 gallons for all other requirements.

The supply from the spring is altogether inadequate and would afford no protection in the case of fire.

At the date of inspection there was no flow in Bullhorn or Layton creeks.

The farms on the reserve that are not near the Belly or St. Mary rivers, obtain their water supply from wells.

The well for farm No. 3 is on the SE corner of sec. 31-3-15-4, 1½ miles north and two miles east of the proposed school site. This well is 180 feet deep and has a 6" casing. In order to get 1,400 gallons here the pump would have to operate 24 hours. This water tastes badly of alkali.

Several Indians came to see me a few days ago, about a Memorial which had been presented to them on the reserve, with the request that they affix their signatures to the Petition. Let me say by way of explanation, that the Petition (if received) was signed wholly by Romanists, and they as an aggregation, resent very strongly our admittance to the Reserve as a permanent Institution.

Dear Sir:-

Since writing you on Nov. 21st, we have made all arrangements possible under existing circumstances, for commencing the work and are now anxiously waiting for instructions that will warrant us in moving men, equipment and materials to the site.

As partly explained in our letters of Nov. 17th and 21st, our tender for the Cardston School was given special consideration and a corresponding saving in cost, resultant on our just concluding an almost exactly similar contract near Edmonton. This made for economical handling of plant and all of the work generally.

Our work at Edmonton is so nearly completed, that we wish to make arrangements for removal of plant and surplus materials. We expect our representatives will be leaving there by Dec. 20th at the latest, possibly earlier. All items of work will be complete and we would like to ship our plant to Cardston before they leave, otherwise, other special arrangements of a more expensive nature will be necessary, before it can be loaded.

Is it possible for site to be decided on, so that our materials may be shipped. Assuming that we load it next week, arrangements for its arrival at Cardston about the 20th inst. could be made and if the present mild weather holds, the excavation at least could be done in readiness for an early resumption of work in 1924.

Several of the quotations given us were based on preparing materials during November and December, and before next spring. We ourselves, expected to buy and have shipped before January 1st, all the materials except finish flooring.
and plaster. We made these arrangements in order to escape the increased sales tax which becomes effective January 1st.

Another feature in favor of commencing the work at once is, that it is a step in the right direction towards solving the unemployment problem of the prairie provinces. It seems very public news that contract has been awarded us and we are constantly receiving applications for work.

We have in the past, gone considerably out of our way to try and provide winter work for some of our men and to prevent as far as possible, the exodus of our best Canadian mechanics to the United States. Our work generally, this year, was finished early and some of our best men have already gone South.

To date, we have not received any intimations of a withdrawal of price, but some of the firms with whom we expect to deal, are getting uneasy about losing what they thought would be a help during the slackness of the winter.

We are not putting these features before you in any fear that we would be unfairly dealt with in adjusting any disadvantages that may arise through delay in starting work, but merely wish to bring to your notice, how much it would be appreciated if the final word to go ahead can be given without further loss of time.

As stated in a former letter, we will gladly assist in any way we can toward choosing a site, if it has not been decided on by the time you receive this letter. In any case, we would like to have word from you by wire if possible, when we can go ahead with the placing of orders and the movement of plant from Edmonton to Cardston, and so avoid the building up of another organization instead of using the existing one at Edmonton, as planned.

Yours very truly,

CLAYDON COMPANY LIMITED

Dear Mr. Scott:

I wired you today, stating that the drilling on the new site for St. Paul's School had reached a depth of 250', and that we appeared to have missed the main water vein; and were starting a 2nd well 100' to one side of the 1st hole. The last 150' was in a shale formation, with no indication of water. Only a weak water vein had been struck, giving about 300 gals. per day; this vein was reached at a depth of about 125 ft.

The well driller is a man who has drilled wells for the past 12 years and appears very competent in this line of work. He expressed the opinion that it would be useless to drill deeper in the shale formation, and advised us to drill a 2nd well to one side of the 1st hole, where he thinks we will have a fair chance of striking a stronger flow at the level of the weak vein encountered at the 125 ft. level.

The Indian Agent Mr. Faunt, and the Rev. Principal Mr. Middleton came here today at my request, and we all conferred most earnestly on the situation. We decided to act on the driller's advice and try the 2nd well, as stated. By working...
a day and night shift we hope to reach the water level within the next few days. It is not the intention to drill deeply into the shale again.

I need scarcely say how deeply disappointed we all are over our first failure to get water—especially as the locality gave promise of the opposite result. However, we can only persevere until we succeed in tapping the water supply which we feel certain underlies the locality. The site is such a pre-eminently fine one from every standpoint that we feel it would be almost a crime to abandon it unless we find it impossible to secure an ample water supply. Realizing the urgency of the case, we will push the drilling ahead, working day and night.

The driller will draw the casing from the 1st well, and use it again.

The Mayor & Council of Gadsdon have officially informed me that, in the event of our being unable to obtain sufficient water by drilling, they will be pleased to furnish water from their town mains. I thanked them for the kind offer, on behalf of the Indian Department, and told them it would be borne in mind. This would mean a long expensive extension, and otherwise not so desirable as having our own independent system.

I am leaving for Gleichen in the morning but will keep in close touch with the drilling by phone. I hope to have better news for you very soon. Our weather continues remarkably fine & mild.

Your obedient servant,

E. Gardner Smith

Dear Dr. Scott,

At my special request, Mr. Guerney Orr, the Department's Architect, accompanied me to the Blood Reserve on the 29th inst., with reference to the proposed site of St. Paul's School. I felt that the site selected might not be the very best available for the placing of such an important and beautiful building. I will not take time now to dwell on what appeared to be the disadvantages of the site selected; Mr. Orr can give the reasons better than I can.

Mr. Faunt showed us two other suggested sites. The first one of the alternatives he showed us lacked sufficient fall for drainage. The second site shown us seemed in every way suitable, and a change to this site was concurred in by the Rev. Principal Mr. Middleton, and by Mr. Faunt. Realizing the seriousness of changing a site, after calling for tenders, we only took this step after most careful deliberation, and subject, of course, to your approval. Mr. Orr wired asking your permission to change the site, and I am advised that you have agreed to the change, subject to the finding of a good supply of water.

Mr. Faunt left to get the well-drillers to return and sink the required well on the newly approved school site, and I have promised to return to Cardston on Monday, the 5th inst., and do all possible to push this work ahead rapidly. It is expected that water will be got readily. I will wire you at once on reaching a good water supply; and will write again on my return to Cardston on the 5th.

Gleichen.
Reference your letter 3rd as Mr. Orr will not return to Ottawa before end of month please advise me fully as to objections to site originally chosen for Blood school and reasons for preferring site now recommended.

(Signed) D.C. Scott.

Perhaps I should have given the reasons for advising the change of site in my letter of the 3rd inst. and my only reason for not doing so was because I thought that, as my superior officer, the report would more properly come from Mr. Orr.

When first shown the site that had been selected for the School I noted that the ground fell away in two directions. This would entail considerable filling in, and additional concrete. The location was on the edge of a series of hills to the West, which largely obstructed the view of the mountains. There might also be a seepage from melting snow, or heavy rains, coming from the higher levels to the West. To the South of the site the surrounding land is very rough and broken with shallow coulees, which would make the approach to the School difficult with loads, and almost impassable in the Springtime, owing to the spongy nature of a considerable portion of the land that would have to be travelled over before a main roadway could be reached.

The site had the disadvantage of being from one to two miles from a well-travelled highway, and, I should judge, about four miles from the railway station and town. Economically,
This would be a considerable handicap in the hauling of fuel and supplies, and subsequently in the marketing of the products of the School farm.

Another objection to the site, - a sentimental one, if you like, - was the consideration that, in putting the School there, we would be practically burying it. It would be invisible from the line of railway, and would be scarcely noticeable from the trunk roadways. In providing this important and beautiful building for the education and training of the Indian children, I do not think it was the intention to place it practically out of sight of the travelling public. Rather, should it not be placed so that all who pass through the district may see the outward and visible evidence of what the Canadian Government is doing for its Indian wards?

When Mr. Orr visited the site I said but very little to him, as I wanted him to form his own impressions. This he very quickly did, with the result that he wired for authority to have the site changed. Before doing this, however, we fully consulted with Rev. Mr. Middleton, and Mr. Faunt. We desired that any step taken should be completely unanimous. Mr. Middleton was quick to see the objections to the site when they were pointed out to him, and concurred in the decision arrived at. Mr. Faunt said that he had already been of the opinion that a more suitable site could readily be found.

Mr. Faunt then showed us an alternative site he had in mind, about one mile N.E. of Cardston on the main highway to Lethbridge. The same amount of land was available there as had been voted for the use of the School at the first site. No other buildings are in the locality, and the School will be entirely free from encroachment of any kind. Mr. Faunt reports the soil to be fully as good as at the first site, and local opinion confirms this. The building will face directly on the main highway, and distant about 250 yards from same. It will be in full view of passing trains about half a mile away. The building will be placed in the centre of a very slight knoll, with a gentle fall away in all directions. There will be plenty of room at the rear of the school for the barn and other outbuildings which may be needed. I have surveyed the site with an instrument, with special attention to drainage facilities and sewage disposal. The School will face S.E.by S. - almost due South. Mr. Orr planted a stake to mark the North East corner of the School, which I have taken as my datum in laying out the site. From this stake we have a fall of 15 feet to a small dried-up lake bed, which will be the final outlet for the sewer, at a distance of 450 feet from the School. The sewage will pass through a septic tank and filter bed before being discharged in the lake bed, and should then be practically clear water. I will be pleased
to prepare and submit plans for sewage disposal, to meet the local conditions.

The view from the new site is superb, and beyond my power to adequately describe. There is an uninterrupted view of the Rocky Mountains, with their towering peaks piercing the sky. Chief Mountain, the largest of them all, seems to stand as a great sentinel in its majesty and grandeur. Such a view should tend to develop poets and philosophers among those privileged to gaze on this stupendous handiwork of Nature, the outcome of her birth-throes in the formation of our world.

The drilling for water on the new site is now going on, as advised in my letter written from Cardston. I have asked the driller to send me a wire as soon as water is reached. I will then return, and set up an engine and pump, and give the well a good test before reporting the water supply as assured. When satisfied on this point I will promptly send you a telegram. I am hopeful of being able to send you this message by about the 15th inst.

From a contractor's standpoint, the new site will be very advantageous. The cost of sand and gravel will be cut in two, and a very considerable saving effected in the haulage of all the materials. The successful tenderer should make some reduction in consequence of the lessened haulage charges as compared with the cost of haulage to the further site on which the tenders were based. If so instructed, I might negotiate with the successful tenderer in this respect at the time the contract is being let, in the interests of the Department.

Trusting that the foregoing information may be considered satisfactory reasons for advising the changing of the School site,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.

Re- Site St.Paul's Residential School.

Dear Mr. Scott,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th inst., with accompanying plan on the above subject, and have very carefully noted the instructions contained therein.

I immediately communicated with the Reverend Principal, Mr. Middleton, and with the Building Inspector, Mr. Gardner Smith, and the three of us spent part of yesterday and all day today going over the ground. We explored the entire area indicated by the curved red line on the plan, keeping particularly in mind the special features mentioned in your letter, viz., nearness to railway where a siding might be put in, distance from a main road, distance from the river, distance from Agency buildings, drainage facilities, and water supply.

We were unable to find a suitable site within the marked area. Starting at the South end of said area the land was generally low lying, and would be very wet and boggy during the Spring months. As we travelled farther North we came to better land, but there did not seem to be any really good sites, the country there being generally level without any suitable outlet for drainage. Also we were getting farther and farther from the railway. At the North end of the marked area the land became rougher in which locality the drifting snow makes deep snow-fields. We would be then far from the main roads and cut off from railway facilities. To get to the nearest railway station it would be necessary to travel over heavy hills and ford the St.Mary's river to Riley, a distance of four or five miles.

Having failed to find a site within the suggested area that we could conscientiously recommend for your approval, we proceeded South of the marked area. Here we met with better land again, and, at the point indicated on the plan, we came upon a site which seemed to meet with all the required conditions. Here we have hundreds of acres of excellent black loam soil gently sloping South Easterly towards the river. The school could be placed about 300 yds. from the edge of this table land where there is a moderate drop of about 50 feet to a meadow-like depression below. At the head of this natural meadow is a running spring which would provide water for stock the year round. The drainage conditions for the school could scarcely be better.

The school building, if erected on this site, would command a magnificent view of the mountains and of the river. It would be plainly in view of passing trains half a mile away, and would be distinctly seen from the main trunk road one and one half miles distant. There is also a good existing trail from the proposed site to the main highway. Thus possessing the advantages of easy accessibility, the school, if placed here, would be peculiarly well secluded and entirely apart by itself, and would, I believe, fully meet with the honourable Minister's approval in this respect. It would be distant by road from Cardston less than five miles, and from the Agency buildings about three miles. There is a suitable place on the railway line for a siding half a mile away. This would be of untold advantage to the school, and would also prove advantageous for the Agency. The building could be best placed to face due South. This would give it the exposure desired by the Architect. The approach to the school would be a gentle ascent, and the conditions would be favourable for the planting of trees and the beautifying of the grounds.

I might mention, Sir, that in expressing the foregoing views and recommendations I am in full accord and harmony with the Rev. Mr. Middleton and Mr. Gardner Smith, and the views herein expressed may therefore be deemed to be the unanimous conclusions of the three of us, respectfully submitted after carefully noting your valued letter of instructions.

I considered it advisable to let you know at once of our selection of the site, and to ask authority to commence drilling for water,—hence our joint lettergram sent this evening.

Our weather continues wonderfully mild. There is no snow, and no frost in the ground. The excavating for the building might yet be accomplished before freeze-up.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, Ont. 20th Dec.

E. Gardner Smith, Gleichen.
With reference to railway siding for Blood School please consult with railway officials in Calgary and advise me if arrangements can be made to have siding built as soon as site has been approved. (Sgd) Duncan C. Scott.

I have taken notes as to the exact distance of the suggested location of the siding from the nearest numbered mile-post on the railway, so I can indicate exactly where we would like the siding in the event of the supply of water being assured, and the site officially approved.

Immediately upon receiving your telegraphed authority to start drilling for water on the new location for the school, I got hold of the well-driller, and saw his derrick set up ready to start drilling on the morning of the 21st inst. He has agreed to work long hours, including Christmas day, so we hope soon to know what Fate has in store for us in this vital respect.

There is not much to add to what was said in the Report sent to you on the 18th inst. If we succeed in getting an ample supply of water on this suggested new site, then I think we will have a happy issue out of all our difficulties. The Reverend Principal is much enthused over the new location, and appreciates the advantages that will follow having a railway siding at the edge of the school farm, and within half a mile of the proposed school site. The Indian Agent is equally well pleased with the location, and states that it will fit in well with the farming developments he has in view. It
will be within easy reach of the Agency administration. From the standpoint of building construction the site is very favourable. The drainage conditions are excellent. I feel certain that had the Department's Architect seen this site it would have met with his approval, as it is free from the objections met with at the first site. The location is a commanding one, yet it will be private and secluded in consequence of being somewhat in a corner of the Reserve, 1½ miles from the main highway to Lethbridge, and a number of miles from the town of Cardston.

From the Contractor's standpoint I do not think the cost of building would be materially altered by changing from the original site on which the tenders were based, to the present proposed site. Though the distance for hauling most of the materials would be greater yet this would be offset by the road being much better, and also because sand and gravel would be obtained very much nearer. The Contractor would, in my opinion, benefit by the change. Should a siding be put in, as expected, then the Contractor's haulage costs would be more than cut in half as compared with haulage costs to the first site.

I have arranged with the well-driller to notify me as soon as water is reached. I will then return and test the water supply thoroughly and continuously for a period long enough to tell us beyond all doubt as to the extent of the supply. I will advise you immediately by wire when this information is definitely available. It would seem that everything now hinges on the water question.

Dear Dr. Scott,

Re: St. Paul's School

In pursuance of your telegraphed instructions of the 20th inst., I duly called on the railway officials in Calgary with reference to the proposed siding for St. Paul's School. The matter was given sympathetic attention by the Railway Sect. Mr. Cameron, and I was referred to the Lethbridge Divisional Engineer, Mr. Miles, who was instructed to accompany me to the point on the railway nearest the School site and make a report to the Sect. Today we visited the proposed location of the siding, and Mr. Miles stated that the conditions are very favourable for placing a siding there, and that he will recommend that it be done as soon as possible after the final approval of the school site by the Department of Indian Affairs.

There is ample room for a suitable siding within the right-of-way, so that it will not be necessary to obtain the consent of the

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6374, file 764-9, part 1)
Board of Railway Commissioners. Very little grading will be necessary, and, if the ground is too rough for grading, the siding can be brought up to the required level by using about a car-load of cinders which the railway Co. can supply.

The Engineer suggests that we should have a six-car spur instead of a complete siding, on grounds of economy. Will you kindly instruct me as to whether such a spur would meet the Department's needs. We can have a complete siding, with a switch from the main track at each end, if desired, but the cost would be greater.

I understand that the practice of the railway company is to charge an annual rental in the form of interest on the value of the steel tracks, switches, etc., and that the customer pay for the grading and ties. I will have more definite information on the cost question tomorrow, and may then be able to submit an approximate estimate of the cost of such a spur as is suggested by the Engineer.

As stated in my telegram of today, water has been obtained on the proposed new school site. This is most fortunate, and is a happy sequel to the disappointment felt on failing to get water in previous drilling. The water was
met with in a gravel formation at a depth of 60 feet, and is of good quality. I have tested the supply carefully and find that the yield is at the rate of 7000 gals per 24 hours. The water rises in the casing to within 25 feet of the surface of the ground. The well is located on the school site so that it may be beneath the machinery room when the building is properly placed on its site.

The conditions now seem most favourable for St. Paul's School, and one can almost discern the hand of Providence guiding and directing us to the most suitable spot. With an ample supply of pure water, a railway siding, the best of soil, superb view of mountains and river, good drainage, good road, ease of accessibility yet with entire seclusion,—what more could we ask for? The location is reasonably close to the new Agency buildings, and not far from the principal farming area of the Reserve. The building can be best placed to face due South.

Yours faithfully,

E. Gardner Smith

Re- St.Paul's School Site.

Sir,-

The Department will be aware that Commissioner Graham, of Regina, visited the Blood Reserve on the 17th ultimo, and made another selection of a site for St.Paul's school. The site he chose is situated in the locality of the original site, and distant about 300 yards from it. It is North of the former site, and nearer the Hillspring road; about 2 miles from the Macleod highway, and about 5 miles from Cardston. The general characteristics of this site are practically identical with those of the original site,-excepting, possibly, slightly better drainage conditions exist at the latter site.

The Commissioner made arrangements for the drilling of a well on the new site, and this work started about a week ago. Yesterday water was reached at a depth of 140'. I was present and supervised the careful testing of the capacity of this well. The showing was truly remarkable. After baling steadily for 30 minutes, with a 14' baler, during which time we discharged 525 gals. of water, we were unable to lower the level of the water in the casing below the 100' mark,-that is to say we still had 100' of water in the casing. This means that our well has the extraordinary capacity of quite 1000 gals. per hour! Whatever else the new school site may lack, there will be no scarcity of water! Thinking that you should have information regarding water supply as soon as possible, I have sent you the following telegram;

The Secretary.
Dep't of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Abundance water secured on school site selected by Commissioner Graham.

(Sgd) E.Gardner Smith.

I sent a similar message to Claydon Company Limited, at their request to be notified as soon as water was assured. The water seems of good quality, being probably fed from springs situated in the adjoining ridges. Mr.Faunt, the Indian Agent, informed me that he has received authority to have a second well drilled for the outbuildings and stock, which will be done while the drill is in the locality.
This means that we must now form some tentative plans as to the approximate location of future outbuildings, so that the second well may be most conveniently located. We have given some thought to this, and have decided on a site for the second well, keeping in mind the avoidance of fire hazard, so that in the event of an outbuilding catching fire, the prevailing West wind would not be likely to carry the fire to the school building.

Mr. Fairchild, of the Ottawa office of the Department, is now at work on this Reserve. I assisted him in taking the levels for sewage disposal from the prospective new school. The conditions, though none too favourable, are not impossible. We have a fall from grade at school site to the outlet in a small gully, of 14.80' in a run of 750', the "run" being the distance from the well (which we took as our datum) to the said outlet. Assuming that our sewer will be 6' below grade where it will emerge from the rear of the school, and continuing the fall of ¼" to the foot for 100' until the septic tank is reached, we will have our sewer about 3' below school grade at point of inlet to septic tank. We will next lose about 2' in getting through the siphon chamber, thus giving us a depth of sewer of about 10' below grade at this point. We now have only about 5' fall left for our remaining run of nearly 650', which means that our sewer from siphon chamber to final outlet can only have a fall of about 1/10" to the foot. Having got rid of the solids at the septic tank, I believe the remaining effluent will flow away even with so slight a fall in the sewer, especially when assisted by the impulse received from the siphonic discharge. The little gully into which the discharge will take place is a sluggish water course, with very slight fall to the N.E. As stated before, the conditions for drainage, though not ideal, are not impossible, and a sewage disposal system, if carefully installed, should function all right.

Mr. Faunt informs me that the Commissioner is having a 2nd hand Ford car fitted up for the use of the building inspector, which will be a boon to me in getting to my jobs.

We have had some squally weather recently, accompanied with snow flurries, but today the weather appears to have cleared off, and the indications are that Spring is at hand. The cream of the year for building construction is now before us.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir:-

I spent all yesterday at the new school site, and judging from the amount of stock now grazing on the land, it is time the land was handed over to us; literally, the "cattle of a thousand hills" were there, including Mormon, Indian and Gentile. It is known that the school is to be built; hence the rush for the pasture while there is yet time. Unless the stock is kept off and the fences put in good repair, we shall be minus both hay and pasture; therefore the desire to have sections 23 and 24, in township 3, range 25, West of the 6th, set aside at once for the new St. Paul School. Once this is done officially, I can act; until it is done, I have no jurisdiction.

When this is being taken up, the question of having Call Robe moved to other lands would be most advisable, as he and his followers dominate the greater part of the half section 23.

Regarding the name of the School; several of the old boys have mentioned to me recently, of adding "Collegiate" after St. Paul's thus making it "St. Paul's Collegiate" or "St. Paul's Indian College". I am very much in favour of the idea, and can see no objection, although I fully admit the advisability of retaining the standard of "Residential School", as adopted. Probably this is a matter of local opinion, but thought it wise to mention it.

In addition to the 100 acres we are to have broken this summer in preparation for next year's crop, I would fain suggest that a sum of four hundred ($400) be voted for breaking another 100 acres thus giving us two hundred acres for crop next summer. If there is any possible chance whatever of obtaining $400 for breaking more land this year, I would strongly recommend that the money be granted, despite the general financial condition. The outlay would more than double itself the first year, and it would give the school the basis of self support from its inception; the main thing we so much desire. This is well worth careful consideration.

The Indian Agent is prepared to endorse our request for the two sections of land indicated.

Yours obediently,

"S.H. Middleton."
Principal.
Dear Sir:

With further relation to the epidemic of measles I mentioned in a recent letter, I regret to state that since that date, many more cases have developed; with the result that the School is now under quarantine, and we have nine pupils under the Doctor's care here at St. Paul's, and five more at the Government Hospital.

I was able to obtain a registered nurse at the expense of the Ind. Department. I brought her from town last Tuesday, and so far as I can see we shall be under the ban for at least a month. Fortunately, none are severe cases, although there has been a shocking scourge on the Reserve; more than thirty children have already died from the effects of measles.

The information given me by the Indian Agent a few days ago, in connection with the land available for our use this spring, being assigned to Indian farmers, was not in the least assuring. The eighty acres given over to us was adjacent to the new site down by the river; now, that has been abandoned; the parcel of land has been incorporated in the lease of a white man. Meanwhile no provision has been made for us, other than what was mentioned in my letter to the Commissioner yesterday. We must have a piece of land for spring seeding. It may be a case of forcing the hands of the Indian Agent to relinquish a tract near the school, but he is determined, if possible, to keep us off that piece. I am likewise determined to secure a suitable tract for spring planting; otherwise we shall be minus a crop next fall.

Had there been any attention paid to our concerted appeals last summer for breaking 100 acres, the present apparent difficulty would not have arisen. However, I will write you again immediately on hearing from Mr. Graham. Water has been secured at the last site chosen by the Commissioner at a depth of 140 feet.

Yours obediently,

"S.H. Middleton".

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have just returned from the Indian Agent's office, where Mr. Faunt and I have been discussing the need and advisability of obtaining a tract of land for spring seeding for the new school project.

Mr. Faunt informed me that he has assigned all the available ploughed land to the Indian farmers; but stated that, owing to the imperative need of the school securing a crop this summer he would suggest that a block of some eighty (80) acres or these abouts be retained for school purposes, for this summer only, from the Cardston Farming Co.'s lease on the North West corner of section 20, and suggested that a clause to that effect be incorporated in their Lease.

Immediately after your visit, 1st May, as suggested, I brought this matter to the attention of the Indian Department, and they authorized breaking 100 acres, but owing to the extended time in tapping the well on the school site, it was not until September 12th, 1923 that authority was received from Ottawa to proceed with breaking which, of course, was too late in the year to carry out such operations.

We are therefore confronted with the position of having no land available for spring seeding, unless the request as above mentioned be granted, or other provision made adjacent to the School.

It is a matter of keen regret that there was no breaking done last year, as that would have given us the necessary land for cropping.

I therefore beg, in consequence thereof, that a suitable tract of land be assigned for our use this spring. The Indian Agent is fully cognizant of the details contained herein. Thanking you for past favours, kindest regards.

Yours sincerely,
