Dear Sir:

Re Land to be attached to the new Blood School

With further reference to the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of May 31, 1924, No.103-1-9, addressed to the Rev. Canon Gould, General Secretary of our Society, relative to the land to be set apart for the use of our Society's new Blood School, I beg to state that this letter having been referred to our Commission for any further action necessary, I have been instructed to inform you that in the opinion of our Society not less than two Sections of land will be required for this purpose, the Sections most suitable being 23 and 24 in Township 3, Range 26 West of the 4th Meridian.

At the beginning of last year (1923) the Blood Band passed the following Resolution in this connexion:

"Resolved that we the assembled Blood Band of Indians resident on the Blood Reserve, offer to the Indian Department, a block of land on the said Blood Reserve, of 640 acres, or whatever more may be deemed necessary for the carrying on of the enterprises of the School"

It would appear from this that the Indians as a Band are not averse to having more than one Section of land set apart for the use of this School, while a Resolution recently passed by ex-pupils of St. Paul's School who had assembled at the suggestion of Mr. Middleton to assist in breaking up land in readiness for crop next year, and actually broke up 70 acres free of cost before they dispersed, requests that steps be taken to
have "two sections of land at least, and if possible, three sections, set apart for school purposes."

When I visited the Blood Reserve in May of last year along with Mr. Commissioner Graham for the purpose of selecting the site for the new School, the two Sections referred to above namely, 23 and 24, were the ones I requested at that time should be set apart for the School's use, and this request both the Commissioner and Mr. Indian Agent Faunt agreed to support.

From the rough sketch attached to this letter you will observe that the west half of Section 23 is in the hills. That half section will be very valuable to the School as pasture or grazing land and by being attached to the School other parties would be prevented from building too close up to the School buildings. I beg to request, therefore, on behalf of our Society that:

(a) The whole of the two Sections mentioned, namely 23 and 24 in Township 3, Range 26, West 4th M., be set apart at the earliest date possible for the use of the new Blood School.

(b) That steps be taken to have the Indian named Calf Robe, who has now a small holding on Section 23, compensated for any improvements he may have made on his present holding and transferred to some other location.

(c) That steps be taken to have the men who held leases on any part of either Sections 23 and 24 and built fences thereon, compensated according to the present value of the fencing left standing, in order that our Society may not be left liable to any claim in this connexion when the land in question has been set apart for the use of the School.

(d) That steps be taken to have the necessary fencing required for protecting farm and garden crops or for enclosing pasture, made this year. It is thought by our Commission that an initial expenditure of $600, would meet immediate requirements in this respect and our Commission trust that as this is a matter of more than ordinary urgency you may be able to authorize action in the way suggested in the immediate future.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

Dear Dr. Scott,

May I crave your indulgence regarding the condition of the road from the main Highway through the Reserve, up to the school. You will recall that a gravelled motor road has just been completed through the Reserve from Cardston to Stand-Off. This leaves two miles of the usual dirt road still unimproved between the school and the front gate. Despite several attempts which have been made locally to fill in several of the holes (veritable quagmires in wet weather) the road still continues to be one of the worst in the whole country side, and with so much traffic, both public and otherwise to the school, it becomes very embarrassing to be requested to bring out a team of horses in order to have cars come to the Institution. Such moreover greatly militates against the publicity of so desirable a public and Government Building.

With the end in view of having the road made passable and presentable for the general public, also for ourselves, I have approached the Provincial authorities with the request that the road be graded and gravelled similar to the main Highway. I was immediately informed that this two miles of road did not come under the purview of a 'Main Highway' and that no estimates could be considered for such improvements. On pressing the matter it was thought that probably a joint action should be considered for a fifty-fifty proposition between the Indian Department and the Provincial Government.

It would cost an approximate amount of Two Thousand dollars ($2000.00) to grade and gravel the road.

I therefore submit this question, in the hope that something tangible may be done in the near future, first, to provide a passable road in all weather, and second, to remove the stigma of having "an unpassable road to a good school".

In connection with the grading, I might say that this covers the pulling of the dirt from the side of road to the centre by means of graders, and I am advised that it will take, approximately, 22 rounds of the grader on this two mile length to make this a reasonable road, and the sum of $350.00 covers that work.

The gravel will have to be hauled two miles to an average point, and will require, approximately, 750 yards to the mile. I might say that in placing less than this amount of gravel on the road would only mean further maintenance within a short period. Canon Middleton advises me that he can place one or two teams on this work. This, however, will not reduce the cost to any great extent. The road, no doubt, would be an asset to the school. Dear Dr. Scott:

With further reference to our correspondence regarding the grading of the two miles of road leading from the main highway up to the school. Since receiving your letter of last December 27th, have interviewed Mr. Stringer a local M. L. A. who personally took up this matter with Mr. MacPherson, Minister of Public Works, Edmonton. The policy now maintained in connection with these roads according to the Minister and Mr. Stringer, is for each party concerned to work on a fifty per cent basis and the Province will then maintain the road to completion. From what I can gather from recent interview with the Minister, he is very anxious to know what assistance to expect from the Indian Department towards the grading and graveling of this two miles now under discussion. I feel convinced that if we could make the Minister a definite offer as to what we were prepared to do he would be inclined to give a similar grant. He seems very reluctant to make a statement regarding the amount voted until a definite amount has been voted by the Indian Department. In this connection both Mr. Indian Agent Pugh and myself discussed this matter only last week with Mr. Stringer, because the road at the present time is almost impassable and in addition to the culverts which sadly need repairing, the road is gradually getting worse and worse in so far that cars coming from town and elsewhere will not come to the school but rather phone ahead asking if a team can meet them at the end of the two mile road. Can assure you that anything that can be done in the immediate future towards the re-construction of these two miles will be greatly appreciated.

Yours faithfully,

May 12, 1934.

J.E. Pugh, Esq.
Indian Agent.
Blood Reserve, Bardston, Alta.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of May 4th, in which you state—

"the Department advises that in view of the fact that Ray and Madeline Cross Child, are baptised Roman Catholics, and that their father is a recognised Catholic, that the Department is not prepared to approve of their admission to the St. Paul's School."

May I call your attention to the following points;-

1. The parents of the above named children are Anglicans. The mother was baptised and Confirmed in the Anglican Church, and is a graduate of this school. The father was publicly admitted into membership of the Anglican Church at an open service on September 13th, 1925. He subsequently deserted his wife and had the children baptised by the Roman priest, much against the wishes of the mother.

2. Under date of October 16th, 1922, a Departmental letter was issued which states as follows—

"A Protestant child means a child of parents who are Protestants; and a Roman Catholic child is one who has been baptised as a Roman Catholic, or is born of Catholic parents; but the father has a right to direct and regulate the religious faith in which his child shall be brought up and that his wishes must be regarded unless there is some strong reason for disregarding them. In accordance with this view if a Protestant parent wishes his child placed in a Roman Catholic school and brought up in the Roman Catholic religion, or a Roman Catholic parent his child in a Protestant School and brought up in the Protestant religion, he may do so, but for the protection of the Department, we demand in such cases an affidavit to that effect by the father. Such affidavit must be made before a justice of peace, Indian Agent, or other person authorised to take affidavits, and the
person who takes such affidavit must certify that the statements set forth in the affidavit were read over or interpreted and explained to the deponent, who thoroughly understood the same. In cases of bona fide adoption, the religion and wishes of the foster father will be recognised by the Department.

On February 16th, 1934, all the points indicated above regarding the wishes of the father and the foster-father were duly signed and attested in a sworn affidavit, made by the father in the presence of Mr. Indian Agent Pugh. J.P. Such answered every qualification demanded by the Department, and clearly stated the wishes of the parties concerned.

3. James Low Horn, the foster-father of these two children, has been duly informed of the present ruling to the effect that their admission to this School has not been approved by the Department. He naturally asks "WHY?", and states his reasons on the following grounds.

When the boy Ray Gross Child was one month old he was handed over to Mr. and Mrs. Low Horn, by the parents, to be brought up as their own child. When the girl was one year old she was likewise given to the Low Horns' to be brought up in a similar manner. The parents in each case severing all rights of their children. J. L. Horn has supported these two children entirely and no support whatever has been given by Cross Child—the father.

The Low Horns are Anglicans—-the Gross Childs are Anglicans. Then for what reason, in view of what is stated above, are these two children refused admittance to the Anglican School?.

Yours faithfully

[Signature]

Principal.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 103-1-10, of the 10th May last, with reference to the application for admission to the St. Paul's Indian Residential School of Dan Bad Arm.

In reply I wish to state that the date of Dan's birth is April 2nd, 1929, and therefore was an infant when his father died.

I am of the opinion that the procedure of having a child signed in for school at that is an unusual action, and no doubt no other motive existed than to be prepared. No doubt the Principal of the St. Paul's School would advance as an argument that so many promises have been made in the hospital to the Catholic School, through the medium of the Sisters, when Indians have been near death or dying, that he was guarding against similar action. There are, no doubt, many unusual practises carried on in respect of pupilage for the schools, of which I know little until the applications come to for submission to the Department.

I am informed by the Principal that he now has a new form completed for the admission by Mrs. Bad Arm, the mother of the boy, now married to Peory Plain Woman, but in view of the fact that the child is considered too young by the Department, I am so advising the Principal.

Dear Dr. McGill,

I was pleased to receive yours of the 15th inst., together with the Circular letter, addressed to all residential schools. May I answer the last paragraph of your letter first.

Am convinced, after many years of hard and laborious work amongst Indians, especially the Bloods, that any education imparted (higher or otherwise) is more than justified, by the future potential results. To be specific;

From sixteen to eighteen years is the most plastic and impressionable age of an Indian student. It is during this period that character can be produced. Up to 14-16 years, all that is done remains very much in the embryonic stage and the discharge of a student at that age, with the expectation of satisfactory and abiding results, is very speculative indeed. Case after case could be cited where parents have insisted that their children leave school, for farming and other purposes, where the result obtained has been of a very mediocre type, as a matter of fact, the average type of an Indian, showing no indication of the education received.

Where however, the extra two years have been spent in school, under discipline and supervision, the results have been so favourable, that same have been remarked upon by both Indian Agent and Inspector, that I would fain urge, that the age of leaving School be extended to eighteen years.

The most striking cases amongst the Bloods, and the men and women who are the recognised progressives on the Reserve, are those who, while not having attained a definite high academic standing, remained in school until they were at least eighteen years of age. The extra one or two years in school is the most eventful period of an Indian's education. A foundation has been laid during the earlier years, but during this time there is always that appeal to the development of personality, which is impossible in the earlier stages. My experience has taught me that it is advisable to leave an open door for the Indian's educational development, for many, yea, too many, have no aspiration or ambition to proceed beyond the official requirements, but the few who are enthused with the zeal for definite progress, should be given every encouragement to attain their desire.
At least, such has been my experience, and the results under this system, must I am sure, be well known to you.

I do most strongly and sympathetically appeal for a continuance of higher education. Such is the only salvation for an Indian, where he may attain a standing with his white brother, and the hope of future citizenship.

In connection with the former students, about whom you make enquiries, relative to the high school work taken, as to whether the results are commensurate with the time and energy expended. All are justified;-

1. Albert Mountain Horse. Took his Commission as Lieutenant in the Canadian Militia. Was killed Overseas.

2. M.E. Speaker. Graduated from the Claresholm Agricultural College. Returned to the Reserve. Built his own house, is a good farmer, and a writer of ability.

3. Olive Davis. Won Diplomas under the Royal Academy of Music. Has since married and lives in one of the best homes on the Reserve. A home which in many respects not only equals the average white farm-house, but eclipses it.

4. Bella Healy. Is now a nurse with the Indian Department.

Dear Sir,-
I received quite recently a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Pugh stating;-

"I wish to advise that the Department have again requested that Ray and Madeline Cross Child be discharged at once".

This is in reply to my letter wherein it was stated that every statute, edict, regulation and ruling, officially required by the Department, concerning these children had been legitimately and adequately fulfilled. No reason was given why these children should not be admitted to the Anglican School. If however, the fact that they were baptised by the Roman Church, acts as a hindrance to their admittance, then I must of necessity, in order to safeguard our Anglican position, seek that a similar privilege be extended to the Anglicans.

It would appear from recent happenings, that an Anglican has the right to place his children in the Roman School, but when a Roman Catholic desires to have his children admitted to the Anglican School, his wish is not granted, thus militating in no small measure against the recruiting for the Anglican School. Many cases could be cited from past correspondence.

May I call your attention to one specific instance which happened during December. One Bernard Weasel Fatt, son of Fred and Minnie Weasel Fatt (who have two boys in this school) born July 8th, 1926, and baptised by the Anglican Church, August 22, 1926, was two or three years ago, handed over by the parents, to the father's mother, (now deceased) for future upbringing. The woman was married to Tall Man, a Romanist. During December this boy was placed in the Roman School, not by the parents, but by the step-father. Here is the analogy; The Cross Child children are denied admittance to the Anglican School. Will the Weasel Fatt case receive similar treatment?
I know it is customary to decide each case on its merits, but do you not think that if an Anglican child is granted admittance to the Roman School, then the Roman child should be obviously admitted to the Anglican School.

This is not conjecture, but reality, and I write in the hope that due cognizance will be given by your Department.

Yours faithfully

Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, with regard to the admission of children to Indian residential schools.

I note that you refer to a boy named Bernard Weasel Fat who, you state, has been placed in the Blood Residential School. No application for a boy of this name has been submitted to the Department and I am writing Mr. Indian Agent Pugh today to give us full particulars.

Regarding the application for the admission of Ray and Madeline Cross Child to the St. Paul's Indian Residential School, when this was first received the Indian Agent was requested to obtain full information and forward same for the Department's consideration. The report that we received showed that these two children were baptized as Roman Catholics and that their father is recognized as a Roman Catholic. The intention of the Indian Act is that Roman Catholic children should be placed in schools conducted under the auspices of that Church and Protestant children placed in schools conducted under Protestant auspices. The Department considers that it is in the best interests of all parties concerned to adhere as strictly as possible to the intention of the Act. Consequently, Mr. Pugh was informed that we are not prepared to approve the admission of the two children mentioned above to the St. Paul's Indian Residential School.

Permit me to point out that, last November, the Department received an application for the admission of William Rabbit to the Blood Residential School. In this case, also, Mr. Pugh was requested to forward full information for our consideration. The report indicated that, although there was also an assumed adoption, the father of the boy is recognized as a Protestant and, consequently, the Indian Agent was instructed to inform the Principal of the Blood School that the Department was not prepared to approve of his admission.

In view of the information given in this letter, you will see that the Department has acted fairly in both cases. I regret that you question our good faith in considering cases such as the above. Such action on your part is not conducive to the mutual good will and understanding which should exist between the Department and its Principals.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Thank you for your letter of January 25th, in answer to mine of January 17th.

May I once again state and reiterate without prejudice that both mother and father of the two Cross Child children are Anglicans.

The mother is a baptized and confirmed member of our Church and is also a graduate of this School. The father - Cross Child - of his own free will and accord, was received into the Anglican Church at a public service on September 3, 1925. The baptismal record of this admission has been presented to Mr. J.E. Pugh.

Further - on September 14th, 1925 - Cross Child - Anglican - was married in the Anglican Church to Lizzie S. Alone - Anglican - who is now the mother of the two children in question. Subsequently, against the wishes of his wife, the father took his two children and had them baptized by the Roman priests. Since a few months after the birth of the youngest child, Cross Child has not lived with his wife, nor given any support whatsoever towards his children. They were adopted by James and Mrs. Low Horn - Anglicans - who have brought them up as their own children. They now desire to place the children of Anglican parents in the Anglican School and in consequence obtained the father's written consent, (which has been submitted to you) to place the children in this School.

All the necessary edicts, rules and regulations demanded by the Department have been fully met. . . I submit that I am at a loss to understand, in view of the foregoing, why they should not be admitted to this School.

Sir,

I beg to state further to your letter No. 103-1-10, of the 25th of January, with reference to correspondence to you from the Rev. Principal of the St. Paul's Anglican School regarding the Weasel Fat boy and the children of Billy Cross Child, Ray and Madeline, who are residing with James Low Horn and wife, that I am now in receipt of a copy of letter from the Principal of St. Paul's School addressed to you, quoting further in the matter.

I have at various times given the Department the history of these children and parents, but there has now come further complications in this manner.

The father, Billy Cross Child, has deserted his wife and is now living with a Mrs. Louis Owl Boy, (at present in the United States) and the mother, Mrs. Billy Cross Child, is now living with John Red Crane, and both father and mother have now practically no contact with Ray and Madeline Cross Child. These two children having resided with the Low Horns. There is no question but that this is also a case of re-baptism, firstly Anglican and then Roman Catholic. The father is an ex-pupil of the Blood R.C. School, and the mother ex-pupil Anglican. Obviously from the Principal's letter, Billy Cross Child was received into the Anglican Faith and then married Lizzie Standing Alone in that faith. Later they were accepted into the Roman Catholic Faith and the children also baptized into that faith. It would appear that Low Horns have and will have the responsibility of these two children for the future, and they are unquestionably Anglican.

I hesitate to make definite recommendations in a matter such as this, where the religious issue has become so complicated as in this case, through mixed marriages subsequent disruption.

STATEMENT OF VICTOR CHIEF MOON, Taken this 9th day of Feb 1934,
At the Blood Indian Agency.

I, Victor Chief Moon of the Blood Indian Reserve, declare that I am the legal father of Helen Chief Moon, age 6½ years and Grace Chief Moon, age 5 years, both of whom have been baptized into the Roman Catholic Church. I now desire that these two children shall be brought up in the Anglican Faith, and educated in that faith, and it is my intention that they shall be re-baptized into that faith.

I have at no time received any promise of any kind from any person in respect of my wish.

I am Ex pupil of the Anglican School, and that is my sole reason for making this request.

My wife, Mary Wells, is a Catholic, and it also her wish that our children be brought up in that faith.

Victor Chief Moon

Indian Agent and JP for Prov of Alberta.

Blood Indian Agency,

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report for the month of January 1937.

Truancy of 5 boys was reported from the St Paul's Ang. School and anxiety was felt with the cold and stormy weather and steps were taken at once by the agency to locate these boys and were located and returned in 24 hours. After they were located I had the School teams return three of the boys and an Indian brought in two, and they were taken on by agency team.

J. E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 5th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 25th ultimo, it is considered unnecessary at the present time to issue truant notes in cases of children of the Blood Reserve who are seven years of age but who have not yet entered school.

It is felt that the school Principals will make every endeavour to recruit children for their respective schools. If they are not successful in certain cases, they will, no doubt, report to you and you can then make full inquiries in such cases. In the event of there being disagreement regarding the religious auspices under which the child should be educated, full particulars should be forwarded to the Department and such children should not be placed in either residential school until our decision has been given.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes.
Secretary.

J. E. Pugh, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cardston, Alta.
Sir:

I beg to state that a matter of recruiting has come before me, more especially in regard to proposed pupils for the St. Paul's Anglican Residential School. The Principal has sent me a list of children of the age of seven years and over, potential pupils for that school. The list contains ten children, presumably of Anglican faith, while a further list has four of doubtful religion.

I have up to the present time issued truant notices in delinquent cases of children, eligible for school and not attending, under Section 10, s.s., but as some doubt exists as to the desirability or use of this section, I am requesting advice and authority to invoke the section mentioned, in obtaining the attendance of potential pupils of the age of seven years and over.

Your obedient servant,

J.F. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, July 20th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your 402-4C of the 15th instant, with reference to the petition recently forwarded by the Blood Indians.

In deciding to allow two months' holidays at Indian residential schools, the Department desired to bring the holiday period at this class of schools in conformity with Indian day schools and with the general procedure adopted in the case of White schools.

For many reasons that will, no doubt, suggest themselves to you, the Department has always felt that it was undesirable to allow holiday leave at Christmastime and short term leave during other periods of the year. For this reason, paragraph 2 was inserted in circular letter of March 30th, 1937. For your information, I may add that the various Church officials were consulted previous to the issuance of the circular letter just mentioned and they expressed their concurrence.

It is noted from your letter that it has been the practice for many years to allow certain holidays at both the residential schools on the Blood Reserve and the Department does not wish to make any change in this regard, provided the Inspector of Indian Agencies, yourself, the Principals of the schools and the parents feel that it is advisable to continue this practice. Please discuss this matter further and make a definite recommendation regarding what holidays over and above the two months annual leave you consider should be allowed the pupils at the two schools on the Blood Reserve. In making such a recommendation, you should state distinctly the duration of these special holidays in order that all parties concerned may have a definite understanding regarding them.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

J. E. Pugh, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cardston, Alta.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your file No. 103-1-10, of the 6th instant, together with enclosure of a petition from the Blood Band of Indians, in which report is requested on the matter.

In reply I wish to state that the petition refers to circular letter No. 159-37 of the 30th of March last, which had reference to school holidays. My information is that, after I had personally informed the Chief and Council of the Blood Band of the contents of the Circular, in so far as the paragraph dealing with the actual holiday question, the matter was talked over by the Indians generally and an attempt was made to have the Council deal with the matter. This I politely informed the Council, was not at the time quite a right policy to follow, in that it was an instruction that should have have the support of both Indian Agent and Council, being an instruction from the Department. I further stated that individually of course, that it was a matter for their own conscience.

One of the Indians, Ben Strangling Wolf, interviewed me in my office, and stated that they were circulating a petition, and said that he felt it was only right that I should be made aware of the fact that they intended sending this to the Department, instead of doing so behind my back.

As far as my information goes, the objection seems to be that the instructions in the circular will cancel the monthly holiday, the Christmas holiday and such holidays that may occur when annuity and lease monies are paid out.

Classification of these holidays have been as follows:- Monthly holiday was usually the granting of a Saturday and Sunday when the parents could take their children home. Christmas holidays were from Christmas day festiv-

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.
ties till New Year's day, a week.

Payment holidays were usually on the day appointed for lease and annuity payments, three per year. The parents having their children out for two days at these payments.

All of the holidays have been enjoyed by this band since the new schools were opened, a privilege not enjoyed by other reserves.

I may say that on Inspector Mr. C.P. Schmidt's recent inspection visit, this matter was discussed with the Principals of both schools and myself, and perhaps, Mr. Schmidt has formed an opinion in the matter after the consultation.

I may say that I am enclosing a copy of this report to Mr. Schmidt at Calgary.

Your obedient servant,

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to state that the matter of admission of the following children to the St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School, Blood Indian Reserve, has been brought to my attention by the Principal of that school.

Ray Cross Child, age 10; Madeline Cross Child, age 8, shown on Ticket No. 175 Blood Band. The matter has, therefore, been in abeyance since that time, in so far as the applications were concerned. The children have, however, been in the school since the Summer holidays of 1935.

I may add that since my letter, Billy Cross Child has been living with many Many Bears in marital state, and is now shown on his ticket, while the mother of the children still lives with John Red Crane, No. 247, and she is shown on this ticket as Lizzie Standing Alone. I am having the Principal obtain further applications for the above children.

Dan Bad Arm, age 9. This boy is shown under Ticket No. 228, Blood Band, Percy Plain Woman. Plain Woman having married Mrs. Bad Arm. The family of Bad Arm being Anglican, while Plain Woman is of the Catholic faith. This boy has been in the St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School for about three years, June 1934.

Grace Chief Moon, age 8; Helen Chief Moon, age 10. These two children are of Ticket No. 321, Blood Band. Victor Chief Moon, are as follows as to Religion: Father Anglican, Mother Catholic. Both children have been in school since 1935 Summer holidays. Applications are being prepared for these two children. Correspondence in regard to these children has passed before, and the Department's last letter on the subject of these two children is No. 103-1-10, of July 6th, 1935.

I have, as a matter of precaution, again questioned Victor Chief Moon in regard to his statement attached to my letter of June 22nd, 1935, and the information is as follows: Father Anglican, Mother Roman Catholic, children baptized R.C., firstly and admitted to Anglican Church later. Parents are now and have been attending the Anglican Church for four years. Parents are living in marital relationship in Indian custom. Both father and mother are desirous of their children being brought up in the Anglican Faith.

All of these children have been resident in the Anglican School as from the dates mentioned, and the matter, therefore, presents some difficulty although the parents in each case have and do now express their attitude towards desiring their children educated at the Anglican School.

The matter is submitted for instructions, and new applications will be sent forward if desired.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6374, file 764-10, part 1)
SCHOOLS

Both schools were visited during the month, and a very even atmosphere prevailing. Class rooms well attended and teachers report good progress. The reports are attached for both schools.

Repairs to boilers at the St Paul's school have been started as authorized by the Department. I noted at this school, that there are three radiators in the west and upper part of the building that have several sections cracked, no doubt from frost, and it occurs to me that to save cost we might reduce the area and cut down the size, this will be dealt with after tender has been given.

The matter of a holiday for the Xmas. season was the subject of conversation between the principals and myself and letters are going forward on this subject. I am of the opinion that the granting of a holiday to the pupils will remove some grievance over the cancellation of holidays.

J. E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

CANADA
February 17, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant with reference to the application for the admission of Helen Chief Moon, Grace Chief Moon, Madeline Cross Child and Ray Cross Child to the St. Paul's Indian Residential School. You may inform the Principal that the admission of these children is approved.

You should again point out to the Principals of both schools on the Blood Reserve that children whose eligibility is doubtful on any grounds must not be admitted to either school without the express permission of the Department, even though, for compassionate reasons, the Principal might consider their immediate admission advisable. These instructions have been previously issued and are extremely definite and the Department will expect that Principals of both schools on the Blood Reserve will adhere strictly to these instructions in future.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

J. E. Pugh, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cardston, Alta.
Blood Indian Agency, Cardston, Man.,
January 31st, 1938.

REPORT FOR MONTH OF JANUARY.

The two schools were visited during the month and the attendance at both schools in classes good. There was however truancy at both schools this month.

At the St Paul's Anglican school, three pupils left early in the month, were returned by the parents and two of these went out again, 190 Luke Small Eyes and Laurence M. Chief No. 227 and Luke Small Eyes was returned by his father and Laurence brought back by the school. Later Thomas Bull Shields No. 209 truant and Lawrence Weasel Fat No. 207 and Victor Chief Body, No. 214. The R.C.M.P. brought back the Weasel Fat boy and I returned the Chief Body boy. Truancy notices were served of these cases on the Parents of Mistaken Chief, Bull Shields and Small Eyes, no prosecutions made by the parents.

The principals of both schools are at a loss to know why this epidemic of truancy. I made a point of talking to the classes on the matter when making my monthly visit.

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Blood Indian Agency,
Cardston, Alta., February 4th, 1937.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your file No. 103-1-10, of the 28th ultimo, with reference to the applications for the admission of the following children to the St. Paul's Anglican Residential School, Blood Reserve:

Helen Chief Moon
Grace Chief Moon
Madeline Cross Child
Ray Cross Child.

In reply to your letter I wish to advise that I discussed, and questioned the Principal of St. Paul's School relative to the admission of the above children, contrary to instructions.

The Principal informs me that these children were taken in on compassionate grounds, the Cross Child children being left with James Low Horn family, and were almost destitute, and the Chief Moon children taken in last year because of their condition.

There is no change in the attitude of the parents of these children.

In view of all the circumstances surrounding these children, I would have no hesitation in recommending their admission to this school.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant with reference to special leave that has been granted by the Principal of the St. Paul's Residential School to certain pupils of that institution.

I feel certain that you received our circular letter of March 30 but in any case I enclose an extra copy for yourself as well as a copy for each of the Principals of the two Residential Schools in your Agency.

It is quite evident from this circular that it is the wish of the Department that all special leave be discontinued especially in view of the fact that we are now allowing pupils of Residential Schools two months' annual holidays. The only possible exception is in cases of emergency or where the older pupils can help at home in farming. Such cases should, of course, be submitted for the Department's approval as far as circumstances will permit.

I am pleased to note from the fourth paragraph of your letter that it is the intention of the Principal of the St. Paul's School to discontinue granting weekend holidays. I believe that such action is very advisable as all Residential Schools are expected to conform with the instructions contained in circular letter of March 30.

Yours truly,

Crowsnest, Alta., June 28th, 1928.

Sir:

I beg to state that I have today received the enclosed letter addressed to me from an Indian of the Blood Band, with reference to school holidays at the schools on this Agency.

The letter speaks for itself, and is a complaint by the Indians of the Blood R.C. School regarding children of the St. Paul's Anglican School being allowed out at week-ends.

In this connection I may say that I have been approached by the Principal of the Blood R.C. School regarding this same matter, and I requested a letter in this regard, so that it could be placed before the Department. This I have not had as yet.

I have approached the Principal of the St. Paul's Anglican School in the matter, and find that certain children have been permitted to go home at week-ends, and I have spoken to one family, Mrs. Fred Tail Feathers, and she insists on having her children home in evenings, and informed me that she would go to jail before giving up this privilege.

I am informed by the Principal of St. Paul's School that two or three families, adjacent to the school, have been getting their children out, and that he intends after the Summer holidays stop in the practice, even for Mrs. Tail Feathers, and letting the Department decide the matter.

Personally, I refuse permission, except for cases of emergency or where the older pupils can help their fathers at home in farming, such cases being passed on to the Department, but have no control over the school or schools in enforcing.

Your perusal and comments in the matter will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

When I visited our St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve in February of this year, the following Indian parents asked me to endeavour to secure for them the privilege of having their children now at this school, spend part of the weekends at home: Mr. and Mrs. Tailfeathers, Mr. Percy Creighton, and Mr. James Gladstone.

In support of their request they stated that they all lived comparatively near to the school, and that it would be quite an easy matter for them to take their children home Friday evening and bring them back on Sunday afternoon. A special reason was given by Mrs. Tailfeathers in support of her request, namely, that her children were specially gifted in the matter of drawing, and she felt that they would make greater progress in this art if they spent the weekend at home under her direct supervision. She informed me that she had given you one or two of the drawings made by one of her boys, and that you had authorized a short course in special instruction under an artist in the United States last year. From one of the drawings which I myself saw, I feel convinced that every encouragement possible should be given to the Tailfeather children, but I felt unable to assure any of the parents who came to see me that their request could be granted. I pointed out, and the Principal was present at the time, that if a concession of this kind were made to a few parents, we might reasonably expect many others to ask for the same consideration, and endless confusion might follow.
From the standpoint of administration, our Commission cannot afford to lose the grant which would be deducted for any children who were absent from the school during the weekends, but I promised to write to you in the matter hence this letter.

It is my opinion, and the Principal concurs in this, that the request should not now be granted, but that it might be further discussed with the parents by yourself, or any representative of your branch of Government whenever you happen to be visiting the Blood Reserve.

As I promised the parents who approached me to lay their request before you, and to advise them of your decision in the matter, I will be glad to hear from you at your earliest convenience.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

TBRW/WH

Secretary of the Commission.
Ottawa,
May 11, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

I regret that my reply to your communication of the 3rd ultimo has been delayed.

The question of allowing weekend holidays has been before the Department on several occasions. After giving very careful consideration to the various circumstances it has been decided that such permission would work to the detriment of the general administration of our residential schools. Under these circumstances the permission requested by the Indians on the Blood Reserve cannot be favourably considered.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Cardston, Alta., September 9th, 1939

Sir:-

Attention Mr. P. Phelan.

I beg to acknowledge your file No. 103-1-10 of the 7th of September, with reference to the return of pupils on expiry of summer holidays to the St. Paul's and Blood Residential Schools.

In reply may I state that there appears to be no reason for the situation at all, and I know of no reason why the difference between the two schools. All parents are well advised of the opening of the schools on September 1st.

I did not check the rolls until the 5th, and found the situation as reported. The St. Paul's School report today (the 9th) that 60 children are now in, leaving 83 to return. The Principal attributed this to laxity of the parents. At the Blood School only fourteen remain out.

There is no doubt that a number of parents of the Anglican School children are lax, and perhaps take advantage that no action has been taken by way of the Truancy Section since 1931-32. I have no other reason to offer.

Your obedient servant,

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Cardston, Alta., Oct. 31, 1939.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLOOD AGENCY FOR MONTH OF OCTOBER.

Attendance has improved at the St Paul's school, where the matter of children not returning after the summer holidays was duly reported to the department. On my visit I found that approximately eight children had not returned at the end of the month, while at the Blood R.C. school, two were still absent. I have been urged by both principals to invoke the Truancy clause of the Act, this has not been done as yet pending authority by the Department. There is no doubt that if this practice was followed, little difficulty would be experienced in the return of the absentees.

Sir:-

Dear Sir:

I wish to approach a matter that is considered by the writer, one in which a mutual understanding would be beneficial to all concerned in its relationship to the conduct of the Agency, Reserve and Indians alike.

This subject matter is that of recruiting children to the respective schools. The writer appreciates that both Churches have their separate and distinct functions, but one feels that the ultimate objects, hopeful of attainment, are those of granting to the Indians soulful good, repose and education.

With that tantamount in mind, coupled with a desire to a fuller cooperation of the forces for good that we consider exist on the reserve, I desire to ascertain if you would in conjunction with the Principal of our other school, consider establishing a line of demarcation.

This would entail, if considered, the listing of Indians of your faith and then those of a mixed marriage, and then a conclave between Principals and assisting Principals with the Indian Agent, to reach agreement in the matter.

This is suggested to you in good faith, only with a view of creating a leadership to the Indians, that might be convincingly apparent to them that our services are for their good as an equitable whole.

The matter is now approached, as a number of applications have now been submitted in which variance is noted.

Yours very truly,

J. E. Pugh,

Dear Mr. Pugh:

I have been informed that Bob Sorrel Horse and Violer Creighton, whom I married by license in this Church on April 9 1928, have recently undergone a similar ceremony in the Roman Church of the Reserve. The act was performed by the resident Roman priest.

I have written to Edmonton seeking information from the Registrar as to whether they accept the official registration of this re-marriage. Will write you again regarding this.

You are well acquainted with the antecedent causes which led this couple to take so precipitate an action. The sum total, as you have gleaned from their many interviews is simply due to personal spite and pique against an influential Indian family and is in no way attributed to myself personally or the Church.

The point I wish to bring to your attention is that this couple are Anglican and were legally married in their own Church. (Bob Sorrel Horse was originally a Roman, but has officially renounced Rome, and was publicly received into the Anglican Church prior to his marriage.) I have baptised all their children and two are now students in this School.

May I further state, that the Roman marriage cannot be legally recognised, as such is contrary to statutory law.

Further, if on the grounds, that this couple may now term themselves as Romans, and that they make any application to have their children transferred from this School to the Roman Institution, I hasten to state that such action will be officially protested, first in the interests of the family itself, as it is quite possible that in the near future the parents may reverse their untimely act and return to their former allegiance, and second, it would tend to create and establish a system of vicious intimidation which would be detrimental to the best interests and future harmony of the Blood Indians.

Yours faithfully,

SHM/AB

Dear Mr. Pugh,

The Indian Act, as you know provides for the regulation of recruiting. Section 10, Sub-section 2 rules that no Protestant child is to be assigned to a Roman Catholic School, or a School conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and vice versa.

Quite recently many of our Anglican families have received various sums of money, from a resident Roman priest, for signing Anglican children into the Roman School.

This is a direct contravention to the Indian Act. I therefore enter a most emphatic protest against Anglican children being placed in the Roman school, especially, when such a questionable method of recruiting has been adopted.

Yours faithfully

Dear Mr. Pugh;-

Replying to yours of the 14th, inst., regarding "Brown Day Chief". This is the boy whom you and I have discussed on many occasions. He was first signed in this School by his father "Brown" Ronald Day Chief who has custody of the boy, objected to bringing the boy to school unless he was assured of guardianship by signing the Application Form for Admitance himself.

On May 31st, 1938 Day Chief made formal application in person, and the form was duly witnessed by 'Joe Chief Body.' Day Chief stated he would bring the boy to school after the summer holidays. He failed to do so, which as mentioned above, has brought about many discussions regarding the manner he was adopting. I have suggested, as you will recall, having a warrant issued. Dozen of times I have requested that he be brought to School, but always met with the same excuse, 'wait till after the holidays - after spring - after Treaty - after sickness," and infintum. At last I managed to persuade Day Chief to bring the boy before Christmas; to this he reluctantly agreed. Nevertheless, the moment the festivities were over, he came along and asked that he take the boy to town, and would bring him back.

Again - he failed to do so. Week after week, we have visited his home in order to have the boy return to School, until at last he gave it out that he was being 'annoyed' by our persistent visitations. He was then given a definite time limit in which to return the child. He then used this time limit by placing the boy in the Roman School, simply an act of sheer defiance. "Brown Day Chief" is a recognised student of this school. May we anticipate his speedy return.

Yours faithfully

I then took the matter up with the Rev. Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant with reference to Brown Day Chief, pupil No. 264, of the St. Paul's Indian Residential School. I am also in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Blood Residential School requesting the boy's admission to that school and submitting a letter from Ronald Day Chief dated February 14, 1940, which reads as follows:

"I Ronald Day Chief do hereby testify that I have never taken my child to St. Paul's School; he has never been examined by a doctor and therefore I consider the first application that I have made to have the child admitted in St. Paul's School as void and null. I want my boy to be admitted in St. Mary's School. I have signed the papers and he has now and for the first time been examined by the doctor."

An application for the admission of Brown Day Chief to the St. Paul's Anglican Residential School was forwarded to the Department under cover of your letter of August 30, 1938. The application form stated that the boy was an Anglican and the Medical form indicates that he was examined on June 14, 1938, by Dr. A. Hurlig. The application was approved by yourself and under these circumstances it is difficult to understand why Ronald Day Chief now states that the boy was not previously examined by a Medical Officer.

I have also reviewed the copies of the letters which you received from the Principal of the St. Paul's Residential School in connection with this boy. Mr. Middleton's letter of February 20 is not very clear.

but it might be inferred from this letter that the boy only attended the St. Paul's School for a short time previous to Christmas, 1939. I may add that the average attendance for the quarters ended June 30, 1938, September 30, 1938 and September 30, 1939, was larger than the authorized enrolment and consequently the inclusion of his name on those three quarters did not affect the amount of grant paid but if the boy was not in the school during the other four quarters shown above an overpayment has been made.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith copy of letter received from the Rev. Canon Middleton of the St. Paul's Anglican School. In effect it is inferred that the child of John Across the Mountains, Treaty No. 4 (Dan Across the Mountains) now of the Blood R.C. School was signed in for the Anglican School. The admission to the Blood R.C. School was recently approved in letter No. 102-1-10 of the 14th instant.

The Principal's letter does not infer that the father, while a graduate of the St. Paul's School is still of that faith. My information is that the father has adopted the faith of the Roman Catholic religion, and the boy in question was baptized an Anglican, and the Principal of the Blood R.C. School advises that he was conditionally baptized into the Roman Catholic Faith.

In regard to the statement regarding the Black Plume family, I wish to state that in our register of Births Deaths and Marriages, there appears the registration of the marriage of Bob Black Plume and Susie Touch Bread at the Blood R.C. Church on the 18th August, 1935, by the Rev. Father Hudoux.

Bob Black Plume was questioned by the writer in regard to his religious affiliation and he informed me that he was now practising the Roman Catholic Faith.

The reference here is in regard to the recent application of Cecille Black Plume, dated December 29th, 1939, under cover of my letter No. 402-11R.C. of March 15th, 1940, pending decision.

It is suggested that the transference of religious affiliations by Indians render school admissions difficult of solution, and is a conversion principle over which an Agent has no control, and if a Principal offers an application for admission and the religion is shown as belonging to that particular religious affiliation on the application form, it is then apparent that re-baptism or change of affiliation in religion has taken place.

Any interference by an Agent in religious matters of this kind is open to criticism, and while the Indian Act does contain Sec. 10 ss2, regarding religious affiliation, the interpretation is surmounted by transference as stated above.

These comments are offered for consideration by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Department of Mines & Resources,

In regard to this Coal family, I may state that at the close of 1938 term, in July, 1939, Coal had a girl, Minnie Coal, discharged September 30th, 1939, age 16 years, who had attended the St. Paul's Anglican School, and the Principal desired to keep her during the Summer holidays, to which the father and the girl objected. I quote this matter, as it has some bearing in the case.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of the 25th inst., regarding Elizabeth Healy.

This girl was voluntarily brought to school some months ago by her mother and officially admitted. In the early part of the year, Mrs. Healy came here and waited to take the girl out for a prolonged visit. When I refused she became very abusive. Later, on a pretext of going to Cardston, her parents sent a car to the school, and she was surreptitiously taken home and placed in the Roman School, without my knowledge.

Time and again, I and other members of the school staff called at the Healy home, to bring the girl back to school. On every occasion we were met with the statement that the child was ill, and could not be seen and that on her recovery she would be returned to St. Paul's. After numerous and repeated visits to the Healy household I demanded from the mother the nature of the child's illness. On pressing the question she eventually stated that her daughter had long since been a pupil in the Roman School.

I informed you the next day of the action taken by the parents and requested that the girl be returned to this school. Weeks have passed and now your letter states that:

"this party is now contesting placing his children at St. Paul's";

It is not a question of contesting, rather it is a matter of legal and departmental rights. The Healys as you well know are all Anglicans, there never has been a Roman Healy on the reserve and there is not one today. Mrs. Jim Healy is a confirmed member of the Anglican Church, all their children to date have been baptised here, and educated in the same school.

Regarding the statement "Jim Healy did not sign this application form himself". Of this I am fully aware, because I signed the form myself, at the personal request of Mrs. Jim Healy, in the same manner that I have signed dozens and dozens in the past, owing to the confidence that has been developed between church and...
people through many years of service. When Mrs. Healy brought the girl to school last autumn, I asked her to sign the application form, as a matter of course. She replied that Jim, her husband, would be visiting the school during the next month or so, and he would then sign his name. I informed her that no grant could be obtained until the child was officially signed in, and would it be satisfactory if I signed on his behalf? To this she gave an affirmative reply without any further thought.

On that authority I signed the Form, which was quite orthodox and legitimate, (because we both know that with this particular couple the husband always carried out his wife's orders), and asked F. G. Striker, as he happened to be in the office a short time later, to affix his signature, which was done without further question. All this was done in perfectly good faith. Had I any idea that such an act of trust would have been violated in the way in which you now state, the Form would have been held over. Two of the Healy children had been in school for a number of years; it was therefore obvious, when Mrs. Healy open stated that it would be quite satisfactory to sign the Form, that it was their intention for the girl to remain where placed.

If you desire to extend the case, I would suggest that you discuss the matter with either P. Creighton or J. Gladstone, as both know the details. Your own official records will give you the character and standing of Mrs. J. Healy. She resorted to secretive and untruthful methods to have her child meet her in Cardston, and then deliberately placed her as a pupil in the Roman School.

Personally I regret most sincerely the iniquitous system of undermining the influence of various families on the Reserve, which has become so dominant during the past few months. To allow this pernicious practice to continue will be tantamount to admitting that the Indian is a law unto himself, and that he can flagrantly oppose any ruling which is not beneficial to his own or party interests. The fact of bringing the girl to school, leaving her here for several months, and then break all good faith and contract by secretly placing her in another school, is conduct deserving of severe censure. Shall be pleased to have the girl returned as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd.) S. H. Middleton,
Principal.
Sir:

I beg to state that Jim Healy, Treaty No. 158, of the Blood Band has recently made request to have pupil No. 0285, Elizabeth Healy of the St. Paul's Anglican School, admitted to the Blood R.C. School.

I wrote the Principal of St. Paul's Anglican School, and I attach herewith his letter regarding the matter.

It is quite obvious from the attached letter, that when a child goes out of school, the responsibility of a difficult case is passed to the Agent's hands, as in this case, where the Principal states that "I informed you next day etc." Apparently it was my duty to issue a warrant for this child's return to St. Paul's, but in as much as this practice is not too desirable, I have for the past few years been reluctant in this. However, it appears that no matter what type of truancy of this nature, the truancy section of the Indian Act will have to be invoked.

In this case, therefore, I am asking the Department for their consideration of the case, its attitude to the changing of religious affiliation over which, of course, an Indian Agent has no control, and its instructions in dealing with this case of Healy's.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 10th instant and also a letter relating to the above noted subject, received by you from the Principal of the St. Paul's residential school.

The officials here are greatly disturbed by Canon Middleton's statement to you, which reads:

"Jim Healy did not sign this application form himself. Of this I am fully aware because I signed the form myself at the personal request of Mrs. Jim Healy, in the same manner that I have signed dozens and dozens in the past, owing to the confidence that has been developed between church and people through many years of service. When Mrs. Healy brought the girl to school last autumn, I asked her to sign the application form as a matter of course. She replied that Jim, her husband, would be visiting the school during the next month or so and would then sign his name. I informed her that no grant could be obtained until the child was officially signed in and would it be satisfactory if I signed on his behalf. To this she gave an affirmative reply without any further thought.

"On that authority I signed the form, which was quite orthodox and legitimate, because we both know that with this particular couple the husband always carries out his wife's orders, and asked F. G. Striker, as he happened to be in the office a short time later, to affix his signature, which was done without further question".

Am I to understand that the Principal of the St. Paul's School not only signed Healy's name in the absence of Healy but also asked a man named Striker, who visited the office later, to sign a document which reads:

"I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document".

The Principal states that this procedure in his judgment was orthodox and legitimate. Let me state very frankly

that in -

Mr. J. E. Pugh,
Indian Agent,
Cardston, Alberta.
that in the judgment of the Department his action was neither legal, orthodox nor legitimate and that this Department is not prepared to co-operate with a principal who follows this procedure in the enrolment of pupils at his school. May I point out further that if other applications have been sent in, signed by the Principal rather than by the parent in each case, these application forms, in the judgment of the Department, are null and void and that new application forms should be sent in at once.

It should be comparatively easy for you to determine the religious status of Elizabeth Healy. If the parents of this pupil have left the Anglican Church and have become Roman Catholics, you should receive from the father, in writing, a statement to this effect; and you should also receive a statement in writing from the Priest of the Roman Catholic Church which he is now attending to the effect that the parents of this pupil have joined the Roman Catholic Church and are at this date members of that church. If, on the other hand, the parents of the pupil are still Anglicans, steps should be taken to have this pupil regularly enrolled at the St. Paul's School.

I am exceedingly anxious that you should discuss very fully and very frankly with the Principal not only the case of Elizabeth Healy but the general practice which appears to have been followed at the St. Paul's School in the enrolment of pupils. If the proper care were exercised by the principals in a great many of these cases, disputes that arise from time to time could in my judgment be easily avoided. It has always seemed to me regrettable that so much of the agent's time is taken up in dealing with the religious status of certain pupils seeking enrolment at residential schools.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 18th ult., No. 103-1-10, and my reply to the same on the 4th inst., I beg to state that I wrote to the Principal of our St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve, (Rev. Canon Middleton) on the 23rd ult., and have received his reply. Copies of both letters are enclosed herewith.

Although your letter of the 18th ult. dealt only with the question of the enrolment of Elizabeth Healy at our St. Paul's School, you will note that in my letter to the Rev. Principal Middleton I also directed his attention to the delay on the part of pupils in returning to the School after the summer holidays, and this will explain why he has dealt, at some length, with this question in the early part of his letter.

It would appear from the Principal's letter that "the system which had been evolved" and which he states "was very effective, and produced splendid results" was not followed either last year or this, and as the system mentioned would seem to be in keeping with Section 10 of the Indian Act, our Commission would suggest that your Department's local representative be requested to give the principal some further assistance in the matter of having the pupils return promptly, than he appears to have done during the last two years.
With regard to the enrolment of the Indian girl Elizabeth Healy at St. Paul's School, I beg to state that our Commission at a meeting held on the 8th inst., after hearing and carefully considering the correspondence you so kindly forwarded to me in this connexion, along with the letter I addressed to the Principal, and his reply, instructed me to thank your Department for bringing to their attention the case of this Indian girl, and to express their regret that the signing of the official application form by the Principal on behalf of the Indian parent, instead of having the parent sign it himself, was not in conformity with the Department's regulations.

I was also instructed to ask your Department to accept the Principal's statements (a) that the action he took in this case was one "of good faith", and (b) that "no application form will in future be submitted without the personal signature of the father or guardian."

While our Commission sincerely regret the action of the Principal in signing the official application form in this case, the members believe that he did so, as he says "in good faith", being requested to sign it by the mother of the child in question. Now that his attention has been so clearly directed to the mistake made and as he himself has declared that it has taught him a lesson, our Commission feel able to assure you that a similar mistake will not be repeated in the future.

The members were pleased to note Mr. Hoey's instruction in the second last paragraph of his letter to Mr. Indian Agent Pugh on May 16th, regarding the establishment of the religious status of the Indian girl Elizabeth Healy, and they also took careful note of the Reverend Principal Middleton's statement regarding "the general practice which appears to have been followed at St. Paul's School in the enrolment of pupils". It would appear from his letter to our Commission on the 27th ult. that any action he took in the past with regard to the enrolment of pupils was taken with the knowledge of the local Indian Agent, and that any misapprehension which may have arisen in this connexion might be corrected by reference to the application forms signed over a course of years.

The Commission share the regret expressed by the Reverend Principal Middleton in the closing paragraph of his letter to Mr. Indian Agent Pugh on April 26th last, regarding the undermining of the influence of various families on the Reserve, and which he states had become so dominant during the past few months. In this connexion I may say that I have before me specific information with regard to the payment of a bribe to an Anglican Indian parent to have his child admitted to a school not under our Church's management, and while our Commission greatly depurate any such conduct, they would be reluctant under prevailing world conditions, and especially in view of the titanic struggle in which our country and Empire are now engaged, to take any specific action in connexion with the same.
At the same time the members feel that they and the managements of their respective schools should have whatever protection your Department may be able to give them against such activities amongst your wards, and that the wards themselves should be permitted to exercise their indefeasible right of individual judgement in religious matters without either pressure or inducement of the kind mentioned.

Yours very truly,

Dear Canon Middleton:

When I was in Ottawa on the 18th inst., my attention was very clearly directed to two important matters in connection with your School, and I promised to write to you re the same as soon as I returned to Winnipeg.

(1) The first was in connection with the delay on the part of the pupils returning to the School when it re-opened after the summer holidays. I was informed that in 1939 and 1940 approximately 100 children failed to return to the School on time. It was also reported to me that all the pupils of the Roman Catholic School did not return punctually, but the number who failed to do so was very much smaller than those of St. Paul's being only about 14 or thereabouts.

When Mr. Hoey mentioned this matter to me he expressed very real concern over the evil effects which the apparent lack of interest on the part of the Indian parents in their children's education might have on the Government's policy re the Indian Residential School system. He pointed out that despite the heavy expenditure incurred by the Government in providing buildings and equipment, and the lengthening of the summer vacation to two months, the failure of the parents to return their children promptly for the re-opening of School could only be interpreted as a lack of real interest in their educational welfare.

If you can furnish me with any specific cause why the children were not returned promptly, so that I may quote the same when writing to Ottawa, I will be grateful if you will do so.

(2) The second matter was in connection with the signing by you of the father's name on the applications for admission of children to the School. This matter was brought to my attention by both Mr. Hoey and Mr. MacInnes, and I was given to understand by them that they took a decidedly serious view of this action on your part.

I asked that copies of all correspondence relating to this matter be forwarded to me, and have just received the following, with a covering letter from Mr. MacInnes, the Secretary:

Dear Sir:

Many thanks for your letter of the 23rd, inst.
May I reply to the last paragraph first, a part of the quo-
tation which reads:

"to restore the confidence and
maintain the goodwill of the
officers".

Until having read your letter I was totally
oblivious that there was any lack of confidence and goodwill.
As a matter of fact, judging from personal experience, I had
always considered it just the opposite. I am very pleased
indeed that an opportunity has been given to discuss the
points mentioned.

1. For many years past, there has always been a
slackness in having the students returned to School after
the vacation, on time. In order to facilitate a speedy return
a system had been evolved, several years ago, that whenever
parents were negligent in their duty, they were served with
a summons and given two days grace, failing to comply a
penalty of two dollars was imposed. Such a policy was very
effective, and produced splendid results. Last year, however,
and again this year, for some reason or other, the Indian
Agent did not issue the accustomed summons, and the Indians
took advantage of the apparent lack of law enforcement. An
Indian (at least, the Bloods) will always respond to the
law when he knows there is a penalty attached, but if there
is the least possible loop-hole of escape he will trespass
to the limit. The fact of non-issue of a summons gave the
Indians the idea that they could more or less suit their own
convenience and time, and when they realised that no law would
applied, it left them masters of the situation. Time or date
is of no consequence to the Indian mind, and one day is just
as good as another on which to return their children.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6374, file 764-10, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
The figures quoted regarding the Roman and our School are quite arbitrary, and have no real significance. The Roman School has always been at more or less the centre of the Reserve. In our case we have been at the two extremes. The Romans had their recruits from their immediate vicinity—ours were mostly from around the Old Agency, some forty miles north of here. Moreover, most of the absentees mentioned were working with the parents off the Reserve at and around Lethbridge—Picture Butte—Raymond—Magrath and Stirling, in the Beet fields. Most of the Indians from around the Old Agency, amongst whom we have numerous students, are not resident farmers like those settled around the Schools; they are nomads, and follow that mode of life accordingly, which accounts for our peculiar difficulty by not having the children returned on time.

I have sent riders and messengers out to these various Camps, beseeching the return of the children. Even today the car is again chasing through Picture Butte and Lethbridge to Taber, a distance of some hundred and twenty odd miles from the School, in order to pick up any absentees. Such is a costly procedure in both time and gasoline. Whereas, past experience proved, that the issue of a summons was effective. To state at the outset that approximately 100 students failed to return on time, leaves the matter unsettled, especially, when after driving several hundred miles, in search of them, the majority were in residence after the first two weeks. It takes time to travel through these neighbouring towns, and the difficulty is increased when Indians, having a boy earning a dollar or so a day, deliberately hide him on arrival.

I am convinced after thirty years amongst the Bloods, that if the Students are to be returned on time, a penalty must be enforced for failure of observance. Such an Act is common with White Schools. For years past there has always been a Standing Departmental order, that in case of an absentee, the authorities of the School were requested to notify the Indian Agent, who in turn would exercise his authority and have the student returned. Such apparently is not now in force.

As you have a copy of my letter, April 26, addressed to the Indian Agent, there is nothing more to be said in that connection. Am rather inclined to think, however, the whole matter has been presented in the wrong light, and in consequence is being taken too literal and impersonal. The import of Mr. Hoey's letter May 16, written to the Indian Agent, is essentially legal and academic. Such an aspect has never occurred to me when complying with the numerous requests made to me by these Indians. When I used the term of "signing dozens in the past", it was made from the mental picture of office and camp procedure. Time and
again, when asking the Indian to sign the Application Form, he will remain seated, and state quite innocently—"Ksestoa, sotim sinakit" —meaning—"You sign it". It was under such circumstances, that Mrs. Healy requested me to sign the Form indicated. Working with these people, day in and day out, year in and year out, a policy of trust and confidence must be acquired, otherwise one's labour is in vain. Never have I experienced an Indian recreant to his pledged word before. Such has taught me a lesson.

The term used in the quoted paragraph—"A principal who follows this procedure in the enrolment of his pupils"—is not very gratifying to a man who has given more than thirty years of bitter hard service on behalf of the Indian. My record amongst the Bloods is not to be judged by the weakness of one particular Indian, who was obviously coerced into this act of betrayal. If the act of my signing the Form was not legal, it was at the least, an act of good faith, and I am quite willing to accept the decision of the Department. Nevertheless, I wish to be quite frank and openly state, that I do not like to feel that something is being read into the signing of this application, which does not exist. There was no ulterior motive whatsoever, and had the Indian been allowed to follow his own inclination, he would never have made application to have his child transferred to the Roman School, especially when his other children were here and this was the School of himself and fore-bears.

I ought to state that the sentiments expressed by Mr. Hoey had not been communicated to me, until I received your letter. I wish they had, as I would have hastened to write further. There is always the possibility when writing through the medium of the Agency Office of one's attitude and desire being unintentionally misinterpreted.

You may rest assured that no Application Form, will in future be submitted without the personal signature of the father or guardian indicated, even though we may have to wait many months for the sanction of the Grant.

I cannot close without refuting the statement made by Mr. Hoey in his letter to the Indian Agent—"the general practice which appears to have been followed at St. Paul's School in the enrolment of pupils".——Mr. Pugh knows that such is not the practice, and I cannot understand why he has allowed the opinion to prevail.

Such is not and never has been the practice. I have always given the Indian the benefit of his inherent privileges.
Secretary, Ind. Res. Commission,

September 27th, 1940.

No one has fought for the Indian's rights, more than I have done. I regret very deeply that such a construction has been placed where it was not deserved. One has only to turn back the Application Forms signed over a course of years, to correct the misapprehension. I am very thankful you wrote me about this matter, which has now given me an opportunity of correcting a situation which did not; has not, and never will exist while I remain at the School.

I trust you will place the whole question before the Department in the same candid manner that I have stated the above. If there is anything further, I shall be only too pleased to state any facts and not fancies bearing on the case.

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) Canon Middleton.
(Principal)

Grant for the full quarter was requested for Jennie Tallow, No. 0231. I understand that this girl has been transferred to the Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste. Marie and consequently no grant is being allowed for her at the St. Paul's School. We have reviewed our files very carefully and we cannot find any correspondence granting authority to transfer this girl to the school mentioned. Philip Phelan,
