Attention: Philip Phelan, Esq., Chief, Training Division.

T.R.L. MacInnes, Esq., Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I beg to acknowledge and advise in regard to your letter of January 14th, File No. 103-1-10, that Allan Standing Alone, No. 219 shown on the Sept. quarterly Returns and not shown on the December Returns, is still in School. I am advised by the Principal that the omission of the name was an oversight on his part.

In regard to the name of Jennie Tallow, No. 0221, you are correct in this case, this girl having been transferred to the Shingwauk Home at St. Marie.

Canon Middleton approached me regarding this girl and I advised him (on receipt of the Department's decision on Agnes, the daughter of Chris Shade) that no grant would be allowed and that any expense would have to be taken care of by the parents.

He advises me that Jennie Tallow will be dropped from the Returns, this girl was sent away by the parents who had in mind the sending of her to a White Girl's Boarding School, but when one of the staff of the St. Paul's School left at the end of the term she offered to take Jennie with her to Shingwauk (where she is now teaching) and the parents accepted the offer and sent Jennie down under this lady's supervision - I understand that the girl has settled down and is doing quite well.

Anthony McMillan,
Indian Agent.

UNDER DIRECTION OF THE OBLATE FATHERS

Cardston, Alberta May 22, 1943

Mrs Minnie Prairie Chicken, treaty Indian of the Blood Indian Band, hereby request that my daughter Lucy Prairie Chicken aged seven years, shall be admitted into the Blood R.C. School to receive her education and religious instruction.

I am a graduate of the Saint Paul's Anglican School and was confirmed into that church, and I have two children in the Saint Paul's School and they together with my daughter, above, have been baptized into the Anglican church.

Since about three years I want to become a member of the Catholic Faith and have consequently had my two last children baptized in that church. It is my intention to be received into that church in the very near future.

I am now living with Fred Mountain Horse who has been my sole support for the past seven years and he is with me to sign as a witness.

Ottawa,
July 2, 1943.

Mr. A. McMillan, Indian Agent, Cardston, Alta.

I have your letter of the 20th ultimo, with reference to the application for the admission of Lucy Prairie Chicken to an Indian residential school. From the information given in your letter it would appear that the mother has contributed solely to the support of this girl and, although the putative father claims he has contributed to her support, you might make further inquiries with a view to settling this question, because I feel it has a bearing on the decision as to which of the parents should have the direction of the child's education. Possibly it would be best to leave the child at home for another year. The matter will be further considered when you reply.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa,
September 3, 1945.

Reverend Sir:

I have your telegram of the 2nd instant, requesting approval for transferring Grant Allen Tailfeathers, No. 224, from the St. Paul's Indian Residential School to the Shingwauk Residential School, in order that he might attend high school at the latter place.

For some years past the Department has been assisting Gerald Tailfeathers, who is a brother of Grant. As you are aware, there are approximately 19,000 Indian children attending Indian schools throughout Canada and the amount provided for advanced education is very limited. As a result the Department has not deemed it advisable to grant assistance to two children in the one family at the same time. Under the circumstances we are not prepared to approve the transfer of Grant Allen Tailfeathers.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. H.A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission,
M. S. C. C.,
38-43 The Bible House,
184 Alexander Ave. East,
Winnipeg, Man.
Ottawa, September 4, 1943.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

Re: Allan Tail Feathers

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 2nd instant and note that Mr. Phelan has already communicated with you in respect to the transfer of the above-noted pupil to the Shingwauk Home Residential School.

Inasmuch, however, as requests similar to this one will reach you from time to time, I am anxious that you should understand the policy of the Department, for the time being at least, in respect to special grants to pupils proceeding with high school or vocational studies. We have, in the appropriations from year to year, a comparatively small amount of approximately $20,000.00 from which we assist deserving pupils and out of which we pay the cost of delinquent Indian boys and girls of school age who are committed to correctional institutions from time to time. At this season of the year, hundreds of requests for scholarship grants reach us, from church authorities, principals of residential schools and Indian agents. These requests are very, very carefully reviewed and the limited funds at our disposal disbursed with the utmost care. It is just possible that a larger sum should be placed at our disposal to encourage a greater number of pupils to proceed with advanced studies, but, at the present time, as you can readily imagine, it is exceedingly difficult to secure funds for services other than those directly connected with the war effort.

I note your intention to transfer Allan Tail Feathers from the Blood Reserve to Shingwauk Home. Railway facilities at the present time are so congested that this season Civil Servants were not permitted to travel by rail unless special permission to do so had been

Reverend H. A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C.,
38-43 The Bible House, 184 Alexander Ave,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
granted. It would be exceedingly difficult, therefore, to transfer a boy this distance, by rail, to permit him to proceed with ordinary high school studies. I have had a feeling for some time—and I still have it—that our field officials, particularly in the outlying districts, do not fully realize the seriousness of the crisis in which we still find ourselves. In the case of this pupil, however, our decision not to transfer him was based mainly on the fact that we had helped his brother substantially during the last two or three years. We did not consider that it would be at all fair to help another member of the family with so many deserving cases asking for assistance. In discussing this matter with principals of residential schools, I think it should be emphasized that while the Department is prepared to help to the utmost extent possible, the parents of Indian pupils should also be encouraged to make a contribution. A large number of Indian pupils have been helped by the Department in recent years. I regret to state, however, that only a comparatively small number of these pupils made a success of life. My own opinion is that these pupils would realize more fully the privilege of attending high school or of taking advanced vocational courses if the parents made a contribution. Human beings seldom appreciate fully gifts bestowed upon them without effort on their own part.

I have written at considerable length, with the feeling that you would be anxious to know the attitude of the Department in respect to this matter.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, December 11, 1944.

Thos. F. Murray, Esq., M.D., Indian Agent, Calgary, Alta.

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to Marjorie Many Wounds. In view of your recommendation the Department approves her admission to the St. Paul's Residential School for the balance of the current academic year.

This girl is now 16 years of age, and it is not usual to place children in a residential school for the first time at this age. I will be interested in knowing what grade she has reached and what school she attended previously. I note that her name does not appear on the return of the Sarcee Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

With reference your letter No. 103-1-10 of December 11th regarding the admission of Marjorie Many Wounds to St. Paul's Residential School, I beg to state that I had her admitted to St. Paul's School today. She is now taking Grade 9. She has attended Crescent Heights High School, Calgary, Alta., for her Grade 9 work to date. She obtained her Grade 8 standing from the Lacombe Home School, Midnapore, Alta. Her Grade 7 standing was obtained partly through our Day School and partly by the Dept. of Education Extension courses. This girl wishes to secure an Academic standing so that she may train as a School teacher. As stated in my previous letter Marjorie requires supervision during her leisure hours. With the sudden demise of Miss Henderson there was no longer any female supervision for the girl.

Indian Agent.

Re: TRUANTS from St. Paul's School, Cardston

1. On the 5th inst., Canon Middleton of the Blood Indian Reserve, Cardston, reported that the following Indian children had been absent from St. Paul's school since the Christmas holidays: Hugh CALF ROBE, Tiny CALF ROBE, Isabel SHADE, Ralph BOTTLE, Christine HEALY, Dora HEALY, and Henry STANDING LIONE. Canon Middleton requested that the parents of these children be instructed to return these children to school.

2. On the afternoon of the 5th inst., I patrolled to the River Bottom near Lethbridge where a large number of Indians are camped, and interviewed Mrs. Calf Robe, Joe Shade and Mrs. Bull Shields where all of these children were located. In each case they stated that they did not have the bus fare to send the children back to school until such time as their husbands received their cheques, which would be on the afternoon of the 5th or the 6th, and that the children would be returned to Cardston on the afternoon bus of the 6th or 7th insts.

3. When at the River Bottom on the afternoon of the 8th inst., I made further enquiries and learned that approximately 12 Indian children, pupils of the two Indian schools, on the Blood reserve had left by bus on the 6th and 7th January and would return to their respective schools on their return to Cardston. Included in this number were those referred to above.

4. The indicated action having been taken in this connection the file is being concluded here.

Augustine Calf Robe & Gilbert Standing Alone - Truants from St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School, Carleton, Alta.

1. With reference to the above and following letter,

Officer Commanding,
R.C.M.P. Police Sub-Division,
Lethbridge, Alberta.

Dear Sir:

It is advised that the following pupils of the St. Paul's Anglican Residential School truanted from that school on the night of May 13th last and are in the River Bottom at Lethbridge, Augustine Calf Robe and Gilbert Standing Alone.

May the parents of the former (Ben Calf Robe) and the guardian of the latter boy (Mrs. George Standing Prairie Chicken), be instructed to return these boys to the above school, at once please.

If it should be considered necessary, Truant Notices can be issued for serving.

Thanking you for your consideration,

Yours very truly,

Sgt. J.H. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

2. Patrol was made to the River Bottom on the afternoon of the 23rd inst., and enquiries made for the above mentioned boys. It was learned that Ben Calf Robe left the River Bottom on the night of the 23rd, or morning of the 23rd, for Carleton and it is thought that he had the boy with him. The boy could not be located in the River Bottom or in Lethbridge where the Indians generally are found.

3. Mrs. George Prairie Chicken also left on the morning of the 23rd May, for Carleton, she did not however take Gilbert Standing Alone with her. According to the information I received from the Indians, Gilbert Standing Alone works in the Cosmopolitan Cafe, Lethbridge where he has been employed for the past year. I questioned this Indian who stated his name was Gilbert Standing Alone and that he is 16 years of age. He stated however that he had a brother Henry Standing Alone who is going to School in Carleton. It was learned that Henry Standing Alone is in Mrs. George Prairie Chicken's Camp. Louise Prairie Chicken, daughter of Mrs. George Prairie Chicken, was warned to send Henry Standing Alone back to School, on the bus leaving Lethbridge on the afternoon of May 24th, this she has promised to do.

4. Ben Calf Robe will be interviewed on his return to Lethbridge, and if he has not taken his boy back to the school he will be instructed to do so immediately.

STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.

SCHOOLS. Both schools well attended during the quarter, except for truants. The services of the RCMP used in some instances for the return of pupils who either ran away or did not return from week-end holidays.

The matter of the above truancy is now being dealt with on instructions from the Branch, and the notations of the Provincial School Inspector's Report being passed on to the respective Principals for their comments.

A number of pupils were hospitalized during the quarter at the Indian Hospital and returned to their respective schools on recovering.

Quarantine was placed on both schools during the month June due to an outbreak of measles, nine cases were reported from the St. Paul's Anglican School, none from the Blood R.C. School.

Premises at both schools are in fairly good shape, and improvements made at both schools without cost to the Department from appropriations. Painting of several buildings at The Blood R.C. School has been carried out, and are quite attractive, using white for walls and red for roofs.

The Painting of the barns and house at the St. Paul's School has been completed, this was delayed due to bad weather.

The High Pressure Laundry Boiler was the subject of Special letter seeking authority for repairs by the Lethbridge Laundry. Due to labour shortage, this work cannot be carried out till after the 9th of July, when this company will have a boiler man available.

The Motor at this school, used for pumping and laundry was sent into Lethbridge for repairs, and is now in use again. Further study of the plant at this school is being made, with a view to eliminating the costs of repair, and will be submitted to the Branch when compiled.

With reference to the above and letter of the Indian Agent of Blood Reserve, dated Sept. 12/45 in connection, footnoted by the Officer Commanding, I beg to report that I served truant notice on Alex Hunt at his camp at the River Bottom, Lethbridge on Sept. 16/45. Hunt stated he had no money at that time to send the child by bus, and wondered why the school did not pick the child up. I informed Hunt that it was his duty to get the child to the school, but if he could not get the money for bus fare to sell at this detachment the following day, and we would see what arrangements could be made. He did not sell, and I have not visited his camp since.

2. Enquiries for the other Indians named above on this date revealed that Joe Shade together with his wife and child have moved to the U.S.A., believed Yakima, Washington, and have not returned to date.

3. Bob Plaited Hair has returned to the Blood Reserve, left Lethbridge about September 14/45 and has not returned here since. Chief Mike Eagle Speaker, this date informed me that he would contact Plaited Hair and inform him that his children are required in School. Eagle Speaker stated he understood that Plaited Hair's children are suffering from Tuberculosis and not fit for school.

4. Ben Calf Robe was away looking for his wife who had left him in company with an Indian named Bottle. Calf Robe was served with the truant notice on Sept. 23/45.

1. With further reference to the above, the following is a copy of a letter received from J. E. Rugh, Indian agent at Cardston, dated September 25th, which is forwarded for your information:

QUOTE:

Officer Commanding,
R.C.M.P. Police Sub-Division,
LETHBRIDGE, Alberta.

Dear Sir:

It is advised that on Saturday evening I interviewed the N.C.O. 1/c of your CARDSTON Detachment with reference to the serving of Truancy Notices under Section 10 (Sub Sections 3, 4, 5, & 6) of the Indian Act as indicated in my letter to you of the 12th of Sept. last, File #4028.

From the conversation with Corporal Pesce, it would appear that Departmental Circular #18-1 of June 25th, 1943, in effect, precludes utilizing the services of the R.C.M.P. Police except in rare and exceptional cases, and therefore explanation is desired as to what action the schools have taken in regard to absent children, and in this connection I may say that both schools and the agency have kept the subject matter before the Indians, and both Principals have done considerable driving and bringing in of children, but other than the use of moral persuasion, there is no authoritative action they can take, hence our request.
Re: Indian Act (Truancy), Indian Residential School, Blood Indian Reserve, Alberta.

We forward herewith copies of correspondence received regarding truancy at Indian Residential Schools, Blood Indian Reserve, Alberta.

2. May I draw your attention to your departmental circular No. 15-1 dated June 21, 1943, instructing school principals, Indian Agents and members of agency staffs to accept responsibility for the return of pupils absent without permission and only to request the services of this Force in rare and exceptional cases.

3. Would you kindly advise whether you intended the Indian Agent at Cardston, Alberta, to turn over the entire 51 Truancy Notices to this Force for service, as it would appear that the appointment of a Truant Officer for the agency concerned would satisfactorily answer the problem of truancy of the degree indicated by the number of Truancy Notices handed over by Mr. Pugh at Cardston.

4. It would be appreciated if we may receive your comments in this regard at your earliest convenience.

H.M. Gagnon,
Assistant Commissioner,
Director, Criminal Investigation.

OFFICE ROUTINE.

In the general routine of the office, the work has been heavy also, with the additional work of Family Allowances. This has now been set up in concrete form, with copies of the original Application forms, indexed with their No. and Treaty numbers inserted on the same form, this has also been transferred to our Roll Records. All cheques are brought to the Agency mail box, and before distribution, the receipt of the cheque is indicated on a check list month by month. All changes by way of births and deaths are noted on the forms, and the copy of Vital Statistics sent forward to the Family Allowance branch at Edmonton. A list has now been sent forward showing the names and birth date of all children over the full age of 7 years, indication whether the child is at school or not, and if not in attendance, showing the reason for non-attendance.

Applications at present in the hands of this Department number 217 families, with 742 children, as at Sept. 25th, 48 children have not been applied for at this date.

Of the list of children who should attend school, to which we refer to above, it is found, that 127 attend St. Paul's School and 161 attend the Blood RC school according to their nominal rolls, and we find 135 children over the age of 7 full years are not in attendance at any school, with 23 children who are being discharged this quarter ending. The preparation of these statistics has entailed considerable extra work.

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Re enrollment, St. Paul's Cardston.

We are a little concerned at the fact that the number of pupils attending the above school is considerably below the authorized number. The Principal advises us that many Indians from the Blood Reserve have crossed the border by reason of high wages and that the children have not returned to school since the Summer. The break in their educational progress is serious and we are disappointed at the loss of income at a time when we are struggling to avoid still further increasing the heavy Bank Overdraft of our Commission.

May I request that you assist us by taking the matter up with the Agent concerned and giving him authority to put pressure upon those parents who are within reach and are failing in their duty. Principal Middleton tells us that the Agent is reluctant to act without support from the Department. Possibly under war conditions it was not wise to try to enforce attendance, but I cannot help feeling that any breakdown in the Indian recognition of authority will have serious consequences. When some can ignore the law with impunity others become unsettled and are emboldened to follow their example.

Commending this situation to your usual consideration,

and with kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Secretary.

P.S. I am writing from St. Alban's, Prince Albert, and expect to leave shortly by truck for Lac la Ronge. Am anxious to see the new road and estimate effects of development plans of the Provincial Government. We have a 44 below snap today.

Re: MICHAEL PLUME - Aged 9 Years.

Dear Sir:

I examined the above named boy at the Blood Indian Hospital last evening and again this afternoon.

He was admitted to Hospital yesterday about 3.00 PM. with a nasty condition of both Feet. The underside of the Right Foot was inflamed and swollen from a First degree Frostbite. There were three denuded areas on the underside surface of the Right Foot that had been frozen and the skin worn off from walking on them. One raw surface under the ball of the Foot was an inch and a quarter wide by two and a half inches long; the one on the heel was the size of a silver dollar whilst that under the big toe was the size of a two-bit piece. The undersurface of the other toes of the right Foot had first degree frost-bites.

On the Left Foot the three middle toes showed first degree frost-bites on the undersurface, a denuded frosted area on the heel was the size of a silver dollar.

His temperature on Admission was 100.4; this morning it was normal; and at 2.00PM today it was 99.6. His Heart and Chest were both normal, his appetite good and he was quite stoical as he did not complain. His hair had been cropped quite short, but on examination I could find no evidence of nits or vermin, and the Nurse said that there was no evidence of any in his under-wear.

We are treating the Feet for the condition found, and also prophylactic for a possible pneumonic condition.

Yours truly,

SIGNED: Jas. A. Key, M.D.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your File 103-1-10 of February 9th last, quoting an abstract of a letter received from the Rev. Dr. Alderwood, Secretary of the M.S.C.C., in connection with the pupilage at the St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School, this Agency.

In reply it is advised that the matter has received the attention of this writer for some time, since my return to duty on this Agency, and I desire to make the following comments.

Indians in U.S.A. The families effected were as follows:

Round Woman - Treaty #416 - Pupils, Eve Delaney #263 & Adam 249.
Chas. Eagle Speaker #115 - Do. Eliza No. 0323 & Lula No. 0324.
Joe Shade #269 - Do. Isabel No. 0322.

Of these pupils, Eve and Adam Delaney - Elizabeth & Lula Eagle Speaker have returned to the School, the latter 2 pupils by Railway Warrant issued by this Office (P 860), the parents did not return.

In the case of Eve and Adam Delaney, the family returned just prior to Xmas, and the parents were served with Truancy Notices and are now in School. Isabel Shade is still in the U.S.A with her parents.

Your Agent, at the beginning of the School Term, sent Truancy Notices signed by self - to Minor Chief Percy Creighton in the U.S.A. requesting that he serve same, but as the families were in different locations, this could not be done.

The Following children:

Irwin Shade #318; Lillian Pig Sorrel Horse #267; Olive Creighton #0265; Ruth Wings #0278; Florence Jessel Fat #0297; Rosalie Tail Feather #0305; & Harvina Madsworth #0253, have all been excused by Medical Officer Jas. A. Key, M.D., C.M., as a result of T.B. Surveys, so 22 Truancy Notices have been served for Pupils of this School the following have not returned to the School: Wayne Plume & Isabel Shade; a total of 26 Absentees, the balance are children who have been in School or Truanted since since entering - 15.

There is a tendency among a number of Indians to keep their children out for Family Allowances reasons, and our Medical Officer advises me that his Office Calls doubled at the beginning of the School Term for Medical Certificates for children of School age.

It will be recalled that, under date of September 25th, 1945, File 402-11B, the matter of serving Truancy Notices was referred to the Branch, but no reply was received, the NGO i/c of the Carleton Detachment RCMP however informed me that he had received instructions from his Commanding Officer to serve Notices (I may add that the NGO did carry on serving Notices.)

To further the cause, I discussed the subject matter with the Council of the Blood Band (See Council Meeting Minutes of Jan. 10th, 1946), I was informed by one Councillor - Joe Bullshields, that the reason it was so difficult to get the children into School, was, that the Indians looked upon the School as a Penitentiary, all of which information I discussed with the Principal.

In contrast to this,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6374, file 764-10, part 2)
In contrast to this, the Branch will have noted that the Blood R.C. School proffered 20 Applications at the December end of quarter, and this was pointed out to the Principal of the St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School in an effort to try and find out why the difference.

I have prepared 32 Truancy Notices for 34 Pupils, some 7 of these are being served at Lethbridge, and the remainder I still hold at this Office. All of these are for new admissions, and I have been hesitant to have such Notices served by the Truancy method in the first instance of joining the School, especially so in view of the fact that an applicant has to be signed for Admission. This point was discussed by me with the Principal.

The matter of monthly Holidays I am also informed mitigates against enrollment of pupils, but such has been the case at the Blood R.C. School.

I may also state that a number of boys have been escaping this School, usually in the late evening or early night, and Truancy Notices have been served in these instances. I attach herewith a report on a recent escapee from the School, by Doctor J.M.A. Key who I requested to examine the pupil after I had kicked the boy up and conveyed him to Hospital. This lad got out of the School by the "sheet" method, dressed in his under-wear and socks only, consequently he was in very poor condition. I noted that this lad had had his hair cropped short and I gained the impression that Hair Vermin were present in the School and I requested Doctor Key to visit the School and render me a Report, this also is attached.

The foregoing suggests that it has been a problem with both your Agent and the Principal, and the remedy does lie in "Using Force" Apparently. It is felt that if Family Allowances were cut-off at the age of Seven years, which was carried out by your Agent (but later instructed to re-instate payments), might assist somewhat.

If the Branch consider that Truancy Notices should be served on parents for the enrollment in the Schools in the first instance, the Notices that I have prepared will be handed to the R.C.M.P. Police for service, and Prosecutions will follow of parents not complying.

Respectfully submitted,

J. E. Hugh,
Indian Agent.

No. 0329 - VIRGINIA C. MOON. - Under School age.
Regarding Absentees for the past three Quarters. The parents of the two Chief Moon families, Wayne Plume and father, and parents of Curly Rider, are directly responsible for the non-return of their children. I have visited these homes on many occasions - day and night - and some excuse is always made about their non-attendance.

The Police have served Warrants -- but all to no avail. Constituted law and authority are utterly disregarded. Repeated visits have been made after the Warrants have been issued -- and yet the children are withheld. The fact of these people defying the law month after month, has produced a similar reaction amongst other parents. If prosecution was carried into effect immediately the Statutory limit expired, an abiding respect for the School regulations would be established; but so long as they are allowed the indulgence of disregarding an official Police Warrant duly served -- respect and enforcement become in-effective.

Another factor which has contributed towards desertion is the refusal to allow an occasional -- festive -- or monthly holiday.

The Schools on the near-by and kindred Reserves have their weekly holiday. The Bloods, visiting backward and forward with their friends on these Reserves, resent their children being stigmatised by not receiving similar privileges to those of neighbouring Schools. The Chiefs -- the Head Men and Counsellors of the Tribe have, since the ban was placed on holidays, referred to our Schools as Prisons. Such is not conducive to mutual
interests, not does it tend to develop an acceptable esprit de corps.

I am writing this as a matter of information.

If there is no improvement in the "T.B." patients, now receiving treatment at the Edmonton Hospital, would recommend their discharge at the end of the School year. In the other cases, speedy apprehension and return to School.

Numbers and names on Form #411 have been recorded as from the Returns.

Re: St. Paul's Residential School

Superintendent Regan has forwarded the enclosed applications for admission of the children mentioned to the above school. When forwarding these, he reports as follows:

"These applications have been completed with the exception of the signature of the father. Although these three children are attending the St. Paul's school at the present time the fathers, Victor and Dan Chief Moon will not sign the applications; they will give no reason for not doing so.

These applications are forwarded in duplicate at this time for your instructions regarding cases of this sort. We have others on the reserve who also refuse to sign and therefore would like to have your definite instructions."

We are in doubt about what action should be taken in this particular instance. We have always insisted on the parent or guardian signing the application form, not only for the purpose of showing that the admission of the child is desired by the one particularly interested in the child, but also for protection of the Department and the school management.

.......2
Once the application form is signed by the parent or guardian, the Department has the right to decide the length of time the child shall remain in the school. If we accept children without the signed application forms, it would appear that legally we would have no control over them whatsoever, and any time their parent or guardian takes the opinion that the child should be taken out of the school, he would, presumably, have the legal right to do so. If such action is carried on by several persons, it would have a very upsetting effect on the school routine as well as on the child or children concerned.

Before making a final decision in this particular instance, we would like to have your views on the matter.

Re: St. Paul's Residential School

I have yours of the 21st, file 764-10 (El) to which you attached two applications for admission which have not been signed by a parent or guardian. From what information I have been able to obtain, Victor and Dan Chief Moon are peculiar in that they have invariably refused to sign application forms, even when they had no complaint with the school administration.

At the present time there are innumerable complaints about the school administration and recent reports from senior officers who have visited this school, are that it is not improving. Under such conditions I cannot recommend that the parents of these children be forced to comply with the requirements of admission.

It appears that the boy and the girl from these homes are attending and in residence at St. Paul's School, and that the parents are satisfied to leave them there. In our opinion the per capita grant should, therefore, be paid to the school.

In conclusion, it is my experience that at a well-administered residential school, where life is made attractive to the pupils and their progress and happiness is evident to the parents, there will rarely be any that will refuse to sign the application; in fact the reverse is becoming the rule; i.e., applications are made by parents for admission to schools which are over-crowded and they are forced to wait their turn.

I am returning the application forms and would suggest that you file them and pay the per capita grant.

G.H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies

Copy to St. Paul's School
November 14, 1951

Mr. R.D. Ragan,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Cardston, Alta.,

With reference to your letter of October 23rd regarding the admission of a number of children to the St. Paul's Indian Residential School, it is noted that the parents have refused to sign the applications for one reason or another. Would you please advise the specific reasons for the parents refusal to sign.

We are returning the applications for the signatures if they can be secured.

Regarding the application for the admission of Delphine Morning Owl we wish to bring to your attention your letter of April 15, 1948 and our letter of May 1948 where you asked for the approval of admission for Delphine Longtime Squirrel to the Blood Indian Residential School. On the application form dated February 22, 1948 for this pupil it showed her to be a Roman Catholic. We are led to believe that Delphine Longtime Squirrel and Delphone Morning Owl are one and the same girl.

It would be appreciated if you would advise why you are recommending her admission to the St. Paul's school.

These children shall not be admitted to the school until approval has been received.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

EDUCATION:

The Blood R.C. Residential School on the Blood Reserve has been filled to capacity during the quarter, while the St. Paul's Anglican Residential School has had some 40 vacancies. February 19th, 1952.

RE: Quarterly Report - September 30th - December 31st, 1951

Education

The Blood R.C. Residential School on the Blood Reserve has been filled to capacity during the quarter, while the St. Paul's Anglican Residential School has had some 40 vacancies. A good deal of effort has been put forth by Rufus Goodstriker, our Indian Scout, to fill the St. Paul's school, but as fast as truants are brought in they leave the school again and the actual attendance has not been increased too much. We believe that the St. Paul's school must be made more attractive for the pupils, both in the classroom and the recreation room before we are going to be successful in filling this school to capacity. Our blood Indian cadets at both schools continue to improve and are a source of much pride for parents and staff alike.

(Signed) R.D. Ragun,
Superintendent,
Blood Indian Reserve,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration.

With reference to the June Quarterly Return for the St. Paul's Indian Residential School, it is noted that the Principal has claimed 30 days grant for pupil # 0398 and has indicated that this pupil was admitted to the school on March 15, 1952.

It will be readily understood that there are 91 days in the quarter, consequently if this pupil was in residence for the full quarter, the Principal should have claimed 91 days. It is presumed, therefore, that the pupil was out of residence for a period of 61 days; however, the Principal has neglected to indicate the dates in this regard. Please inform the Principal that on all future returns he must show the dates and account for absences when he claims less than the prescribed number of days in the quarter.

The Principal has claimed 62 days grant for pupil # 0400. This should have read 61 days. We are amending the return in this respect. The Principal has claimed 61 days for pupil # 333 which is less than the prescribed number of days in the quarter. Please advise the date these pupils left the residence and later returned if they did.

On the Return the Principal has included a number of pupils who are either in a Public School or have been truant for three to seven quarters. We have one pupil who has been in the Charles Camsell Hospital for
ten quarters or a period of two and one-half years. It would be appreciated if on your next visit to the school you would review the Quarterly Return with the Principal and discuss the pupils concerned and if you decide that any of these pupils will not be returning to the St. Paul's school you should instruct the Principal to include them on the September Quarterly Return and Form I.A. 411 requesting their discharge and when their discharge is approved, these children should be dropped from future returns.

You may advise the Principal that we are allowing 213 days from September 1 to April 30, 1952 for Delphine Morning Owl as requested.

George Good Striker graduated from the St. Paul's Anglican School last year. His father is deceased and his mother, who is living, is Anglican. His brother, Rufus Good Striker, is Anglican, but Rufus' wife is Roman Catholic and all the Rufus Good Striker children have been baptized Roman Catholic.

George Good Striker wishes to go to Day School at the Blood R.C. Residential School this year in Grade 8 and reside at his brother's home which is a ¼ of a mile from the Blood R.C. School. MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Eagle Speaker Family

This family is from the Blood Agency in the Province of Alberta. Both parents are living. In 1951 Peggy and Mary Elizabeth Eagle Speaker were admitted to the St. Paul (C.E.) Indian Residential School. Applications for admission received at that time indicated that the family was of the Anglican Faith. These applications were signed by the father, Tom Eagle Speaker.

These children remained in the St. Paul's (C.E.) School until June 30, 1952. They did not return to this school in September 1952 and as far as we know are not attending any school at the present time. Attached is a letter marked "A", signed by Tom Eagle Speaker requesting that his children Peggy and Mary Elizabeth attend the St. Mary's (R.C.) (Blood) Indian Residential School.

Attached is a memorandum marked "B" signed by Father L. Lavern, O.M.I., of the Blood R.C. Residential School regarding the marriage and baptisms of the Eagle Speakers.

Attached are copies of correspondence between Superintendent Regan and the Superintendent of Education regarding these children.

It would be appreciated if a ruling were given on Mr. Eagle Speaker's request that his children be placed in the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School.

Director.
MEMORANDUM FOR:

MAJOR MACKAY

Re: Eagle Speaker Family

Please refer to your memorandum of November 21st regarding the above-mentioned family. It is noted that during the scholar year 1951-52 Peggy and Mary Elizabeth Eagle Speaker were admitted to the St. Paul (C.E.) Indian Residential School as at that time the application indicated that the family was of the Anglican faith.

On August 8, the father Tom Eagle Speaker signed a document requesting that his daughters attend the St. Mary Roman Catholic School during the 1952-53 school term.

In deciding what school these children should attend, it is necessary to determine the religion of the father. It would appear from the certificate signed by Father Lavern that the father and mother were baptized Roman Catholics and that they were married according to the Roman Catholic rites in 1937. From this evidence it would appear that both parents are Roman Catholics, and consequently their children should attend a school conducted under the Roman Catholic auspices.

(Sgd) Laval Fortier.
Ottawa, December 22, 1952.

Mr. R.D. Ragan,
Superintendent Indian Agency,
Cardston, Alberta.

The request for the admission of Peggy and Mary Elizabeth Eagle Speaker to the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School has been received and carefully considered. The following ruling has been made:

"It would appear from the certificate signed by Father Lavern that the father and mother were baptized Roman Catholics and that they were married according to the Roman Catholic rites in 1937. From this evidence it would appear that both parents are Roman Catholics, and consequently their children should attend a school conducted under the Roman Catholic auspices".

In view of the above ruling the Department approves the admission of these children to the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School as grant-earning pupils. Please advise the Principal in this regard and arrange to have the children placed in the school as soon as possible.

MFT/HM

Director.

Mr. R.D. Ragan,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Cardston, Alta.,

With reference to your letter of April 20th regarding the admission of Cecil and Joseph Holy White Man to the St. Paul's Indian Residential School, we have now received a ruling on these applications. It was ruled:

"The parents of these children were married according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church and the children have been baptized in the Roman Catholic Church. The father has been baptized by a priest of the Roman Catholic Church. Since the mother is of the Roman Catholic Church the children should attend the Roman Catholic School".

In view of this ruling the admission of the above-mentioned boys to the St. Paul's C.E. Indian Residential School is, therefore, denied.

Please advise Mrs. Holy White Man of this ruling.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

MEMORANDUM FOR:

THE A/DIRECTOR OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Reference your memorandum of May 21 regarding the application for the admission of Joseph and Cecil Holy White Man to St. Paul (C.E.) Indian Residential School. The parents of these children were married according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church and the children have been baptized in the Roman Catholic Church. From the information supplied, it appears that the deceased father, Cecil Holy White Man would have been baptized by a priest of the Roman Catholic Church. Your memorandum indicates that Mrs. Holy White Man is now living in common-law relationship with Many Grey Horses, but the religion of the mother Bridget Black Water is not mentioned. If she is of the Roman Catholic faith, the children should attend a Roman Catholic school. However, if she is not a Roman Catholic, as she is the responsible parent and has signed an application for the admission of her children to St. Paul (C.E.) school, they should be admitted to a Protestant school.

(Sgd) Laval-Fortier.
Ottawa, May 21, 1953.

MEMORANDUM TO DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Holy White Man Family

This family is from the Blood Agency in the Province of Alberta.

Mrs. Holy White Man completed applications, (marked "A") requesting the admission of Joseph and Cecil, aged five and six respectively to the St. Paul's (C.E.) Indian Residential School.

Attached (marked "B") is an extract from the Church records indicating that the parents were married in the Blood (R.C.) Indian Residential School by Father J.L. Levern, O.M.I.

Attached (marked "C" and "D") are extracts from the Church records of the Blood (R.C.) Indian Residential School indicating that both boys were baptized according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church.

The father, Cecil Holy White Man, whose Certificate of Baptism (marked "E") is attached, is deceased and Mrs. Holy White Man is living in common-law relationship with Many Grey Horses, who is an Anglican.
In view of the circumstances indicated in the previous paragraph, although both children are under school age, it is felt that in their best interest they should be placed in a residential school.

It would be appreciated if a ruling were given on these applications.

H. M. JONES

Acting Director.

Blood Indian Agency.
Cardston, Alta.
Sept. 30th 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch. Dept. of Mines and Resources. Ottawa, Ont.

I beg to submit herewith my report for the Quarter ending September 30th 1946.

Both schools have been visited during the opening month of Sept. for checking attendance records, but time has not permitted any further check than the rolls of both schools and urgent work as requested by the Principals.

The attendance is as follows:
St Paul's Anglican School, as at Sept 23rd 101 pupils in attendance.
Blood R.C. School, " " " 23rd 157 " " "

The roll attendance should be as follows:
St Paul's School: 141, and the Blood R.C. School, 166.

This is a marked improvement over this period last year, and is accounted for by the fact that the Family Allowances have been held pending this check up, and the submission of attendance lists to that Department.

There are a number of pupils who have not returned to school who are absent in the U.S.A., these number 7 children, and of these two are not likely to return having crossed into the States consequent upon a family separation namely James Big Throat, this was called to the attention of the Branch, early this spring.

Your Agent has no method of approachment to this problem. Still a number are out with their parents working off the reserve, and anticipate that conveyance will be sent for their children. The Anglican school are contributing to this by sending out for pupils. This does not affect the Blood R.C. School, as their pupils are fairly good at returning after summer holidays.

I have commented under buildings on this phase of the schools, but attention is again drawn to the matter of the Water Tower at the St Paul's School, as they are now only able to hold about 15,000 gallons of water in the tower due to its condition.

Attention will be given to the repairs authorized for the roof at the St Paul's School, and Mr Weston of Cardston has been asked to carry out this work.

Teaching Staffs are at full strength at both schools, and I am assured that the children are settling down to class room work fairly well.

J.E. Pugh
Indian Agent.

(1) With reference to the above, at approximately 7:00 P.M. on 8-1-47 I received a L/D telephone call from Owen Middleton, L/C of the St. Paul's Residential School on the Blood Indian Reserve near Cardston, Alberta, who informed me that Mildred Halely, aged sixteen years, had left that school without authority and that she was thought to be in the vicinity of MacLeod. Owen Middleton requested that I make an effort to locate this Indian girl and if successful to hold her at this detachment pending the arrival of an escort to take her back to school.

(2) Shortly after receiving the above-mentioned telephone call I located Mildred Halely at the Liberty Cafe near the C.P.R. Depot in the Town of MacLeod. She was taken to this detachment and held. I then communicated with Owen Middleton via L/D telephone and advised him that this girl was being held here. He stated that escorts would arrive in MacLeod for her on 9-1-47.

(3) At 6:00 A.M. on 9-1-47 authorities arrived at this detachment from the St. Paul's school and this Indian girl, together with her personal effects, was handed over to them to be escorted back to the school in question.

(4) As there is nothing further to be done in this connection I am concluding the file.

Many thanks for the correction of the vacation period. The Returns have been corrected; same are returned herewith.

Have made the necessary applications for discharge, based on the non-attendance record, especially the one who has been in U.S.A. for so long. There are four still there, who have not returned since the vacation.

Pupil No. 237 - Floyd Fox - is in residence. Tentative arrangements were being made during the holidays for him to enter Olds School of Agriculture in September. It was found that he had not sufficient academic qualification for entrance. His parents presented this matter to the Indian Agent, who suggested that the boy remain at St. Paul's for another year. The case was to be explained to you. Trust you will endorse the action on the boy's behalf, as he is worthy of receiving higher education.

Reference your letter 103-1-10 (E.l) of the 25th May.

May we explain the signatures on the school application forms of Dale Cotton, Roy Tallow and the No Runner children.

In the case of Dale Cotton - the father and mother are both deceased and the Grandfather (the mother's parent) is looking after Dale and has signed for him.

In the case of Roy Tallow - the father is dead and the mother has signed; in the cases of the No Runner children - the father is very illiterate and the mother has signed.

We hope that this information is satisfactory and are sorry that it was not included with the original applications. We wish to apologize for the lateness in answering this letter, it was just brought to light.

I noted that the Blood R.C. Sir:

I have the honor to submit herewith Report for the month of May 1941 together with Copy of Diary for the same month.

Schools: Both Schools were visited during the month several times, Mr Doucet gave considerable instruction at both Schools, regarding Manual Training in the Schools and it is hoped will greatly assist in inaugurating Manual training in both Schools.

Anthony McMillan
Warden in Charge.
Ottawa,
August 8, 1941.

Reverend Sir:

As I advised you in my letter of March 24 the Department attempted to emphasize the importance of manual training in Indian schools by having Mr. A.J. Doucet of this Branch visit your school during the past few months. At that time he outlined the policy of the Branch regarding manual training and endeavoured to explain the matter as fully as possible to your teachers.

Due to present conditions it will not be possible for the Department to allow any large amount in order to encourage the teaching of manual training in your school. However, it is hoped that you will co-operate with us in having this work commence during the academic year 1941-42.

To assist you in this regard Mr. Doucet is preparing a curriculum covering woodwork especially which it is hoped will be followed at your school during the coming academic term.

At the time of his visit Mr. Doucet made a careful check on the equipment that you have and has made definite recommendations to me regarding the additional equipment which he considers should be supplied in order to carry out the curriculum that you will receive. The cost of these tools will be borne by the Department and in addition you may expend an amount of $25.00 for necessary material.

Rev. Can. S. Middleton,
Principal,
St. Paul's Indian Residential School,
Cardston, Alta.
You will realize that the Department's wishes in regard to manual training can only be carried out with the co-operation of yourself and I feel certain that you recognize the value of this training and that the school management will provide at their own expense the space required for the classes and arrange to have some member of the staff follow the curriculum that you will receive.

I understand that you have a small shop that is available for this work and I presume that you are quite willing to arrange for a member of the staff to teach the pupils.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, ONTARIO.

Dear Sir:

You were good enough to include the Elkhorn School as one for which a special grant would be given by the Department to assist with the salary of a Manual Training Instructor. We have been most anxious to secure such a person at Elkhorn but have failed up to the present. A suitable man was ready to take the position but has been unable to secure his discharge from the Army. I wonder if you would feel disposed to transfer this offer to St. Paul's School, Cardston? We have regular instruction being given there by Mr. H. Dowdle. The Principal writes of him in these terms:

"This man is very efficient, and is a good teacher. He has introduced several lines of Training—woodwork—painting—sewing—leatherwork. This branch has already received the commendation of the Department.

As this is an 'extra' from the usual academic routine, would it be possible, as the Department requested this training be instituted, that they make a Grant, towards both equipment and the Salary of the Instructor."

Mr. Dowdle is engaged on a part-time service and receives a salary of £36.00 per month but I believe your Agent would testify as to the quality and variety of the instruction being given. As this school has been unable to secure a full quota of pupils owing to a number of the blood families being absent in Montana, your assistance would be appreciated.

Thanking you, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Attached hereto is a voucher in favor of the Cahoon Lumber Company in the amount of $65.89.

This voucher covers cost of material used in the Manual Training Shop at St. Paul's Anglican Residential School on the Blood Reserve.

This material has been put to good use in training the older boys of this school in woodworking and many worthwhile pieces of equipment have been made for the school; payment is recommended.

R.D. Ragan
Superintendent.
Colonel Neary:

Blood (C.E.) Indian Residential School:

Vocational Training

(a) Woodwork: This is centred in a small (12' by 16') room that was intended for a refrigerator. There are two work benches. The boys are instructed at the rate of two per half-day with one boy only on Saturday morning; none, apparently, on Saturday afternoons or Sundays. According to a list made up on February 1st, twenty-one boys would, accordingly, receive the attention of the instructor for one half-day per week. But when the attested photos were taken on April 22nd, truancy had considerably reduced the number under instruction. (One boy not shown has gone to get the cows for milking.)

The instructor, Mr. J.W. Mould, is a carpenter of the old school, habituated to the apprentice system. It would be asking too much to expect him to conduct classes in the usual way, unless he were given more space, more equipment, and copies of the woodwork course designed by Mr. Doucet. His present salary of $30 compares favourably with the $52 average of the academic subjects teachers.

(b) Handicrafts for Girls:

Each afternoon a group of about ten girls assemble for instruction in knitting, loom-weaving, cut-work. The classes do not properly correspond with the grades, and thus do not afford a real lightening of the academic teachers' load. The room pictured is also used in the mornings by the smallest children for language lessons.

(c) Needlework: No garments are made. Patching, mending and darnning are done by the girls (not on a class system) for the girls, and by the smaller boys for the boys. The product varies from good to pathetic, but it has to be worn.

(d) Other activities: (Page two follows).

Blood (C.E.) Indian Residential School:

Vocational Training:

(d) Other Activities: Boys and girls perform many of the ordinary housekeeping duties and other work incidental to a home on a farm. Most of this work is done at other than class-room hours. Lists of duties are published from time to time showing the names of pupils assigned thereto. Below is shown the latest list of boys' duties with the number of boys employed and my notes in some cases:

Farm: Morning: 1 varying duties
Afternoon 1 ashes

Engine room: Morning: 1 ashes

Bake-room: Morning: 4; 6.15-8.45 A.M. They each knead a big tub of dough, lacking a bread-mixer.

Cow stables: 6
Piggery: 2

Rectory: 1 - fetches fuel and milk for the principal's wife.
"Cottage" 1 - fetches milk and eggs for the vice-principal's family.

Kitchen: 2 fetch-and-carry
Senior dormitory: 2 tidying up
Intermediate " 2 "
Junior dorms(2) 5 "
Washroom 2 "
Basins 1 "
Stairs - scrub 1
- sweep 1
- dust 1
Halls #2 & 3 2 1
Main floor and basement 1
Playroom 3 (they do the job with wet hand-cloths. Mops are said to be "on order".)
Backdoor and path 1 Not clear what this boy does. Not much evidence of his being on the job.

--------

Duties above are for the boys' side and the outside. Girls perform similarly on their side, and in addition do the table-setting, dish-washing, tidying up the dining-room, paring vegetables, and waiting table for the staff.

Janitor work in the class-rooms is done by the pupils right after four o'clock.

--------

It might improve morale if the farm and kitchen chores could be dealt with in the class-room and related to language, arithmetic, drawing and religious education.

--------

The "half-day" system reaches into all four class-rooms in whole or in part. Even the beginners receive direction, mostly in language, in the mornings only.

Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Manual Training Instructor, Blood Indian Reserve

Last academic year, as you know, Mr. F.R. Weiler of Cardston, a qualified manual training instructor, spent each Saturday at St. Paul's Residential School instructing pupils there in woodworking etc. Mr. Weiler did a good job at St. Paul's and I have approached him with the idea of working at both residential schools on this Reserve this year.

It would be my idea that Mr. Weiler spend each Saturday at St. Paul's Residential School and two evenings each week at the Blood R.C. Residential School; Saturday's time would be from 9 a.m. until 5 p.m. and each evening from 5:30 p.m. to 9 p.m. which would give each school approximately the same instructional hours. Mr. Weiler has stated that he would be glad to do this work at a charge of $10.00 per school per week or $20.00 each week. Would the Department authorize the securing of Mr. Weiler's services under this arrangement?

In replying we would like to know whether or not any arrangements are being made for full time manual training instructor for the Blood Indian Reserve as I believe Mr. Weiler might be interested; he is a young man, well qualified and interested in his work and would be a distinct asset if we could secure his services.

I have asked Mr. Weiler to give me a list of the immediate requirements in woodworking tools which he considers necessary at each school and if his services are authorized, we will forward a requisition for this equipment.

R.D. Regan,
Superintendent,

Manual Training Instructor - Blood Indian Reserve

Reference is to your letter of September 12.

The hours of instruction proposed should be further discussed with the school principals so that there may be some assurance that there will be classes large enough to justify the salary paid and that the individuals who compose the classes will attend consecutive sessions and work on a planned progressive programme.

During the last quarter of the previous school year a salary of forty dollars ($40) a month was paid in respect of St. Paul's school. Attendance statistics were:

| Month | Number of Pupils | Sessions | Pupil Hours |
|-------|------------------|----------|-------------|
| April | 26               | 4        | 114         |
| May   | 22               | 4        | 76          |
| June  | 26               | 4        | 284         |

There is an unevenness about the figures in the last column which invites such questions as:
(1) Are all the older boys to attend regularly?
(2) Do the pupils go home for week-ends?
(3) Are Saturday afternoon sessions likely to compete with other activities?
(4) Does parent reaction to this programme seem favourable?

In regard to the commencement of classes at the Roman Catholic Residential School there are questions on which
further assurance is desired:

(5) Is the instructor acceptable to the Principal?
(6) How many pupils will receive this training?
(7) Are the evening hours suggested likely to be convenient and educationally productive?

You will understand that our purpose is to increase and improve the work in manual training which of late years on this reserve has not been all that is desired. All suggestions for the employment of Mr. Weller are receiving the most sympathetic consideration, and we shall welcome the early receipt of the additional information requested above.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Manual Training Instructor - Blood Indian Reserve

I have your letter of the 21st of September, file 764-11 (E 3) regarding the above.

Please be advised that before our letter of September 12th was written the subject of a manual training instructor for the Reserve was fully discussed between principals of both schools and myself. We are definitely of the opinion that with the present quarters, the increased pupilage and the enthusiasm of the pupils a full time manual training instructor should be obtained for this Reserve as soon as possible. However, as it seemed unlikely that this was to be a reality for this school year we felt that Mr. Weiler as a part-time instructor would be very valuable. As stated before hours of instruction, adequate classes and so forth was fully discussed with the principals before my letter of the 12th of September was written and the hours of instruction as set out met with the approval of both principals and there is no doubt that the classes will be large enough to justify the salary paid to Mr. Weiler.

In your letter you quote attendance statistics of the last quarter of the previous school year at St. Paul's School. It must be pointed out here that teaching was done last year in a small ice house where no more than six people could get into the building at one time, but even in these restricted quarters good results were shown and everyone was pleased. This year with rooms set aside in the basement of the new classroom block larger classes can be accommodated and better results are bound to occur.

In answer to your questions in the third paragraph of your letter of the 21st of September-

1. The older boys are all attending Manual Training classes regularly.
2. The pupils do not go home for weekends.
3. There is great interest in manual training and Saturday afternoon sessions are not likely to compete with other activities.
4. Parent reaction to this program is most favorable.
In reply to your questions regarding the Roman Catholic Residential School:

5. The instructor is very acceptable to the Principal although, as stated before, both principals and myself feel that this Reserve should have a fulltime instructor.

6. We plan on starting four classes of ten boys each at this school or a total of 40 pupils - more will be taken on as the work progresses.

7. The evening hours as suggested will certainly be educational productive; again, they are not as convenient as would be if this Reserve had a fulltime instructor, but at the moment if we are to have Manual Training at all this seems to be the only alternative.

We would like to state again here that principals, pupils and parents are most enthusiastic over manual training. We now have excellent quarters for the carrying out of this training and we would earnestly recommend that a fulltime instructor be employed for this Reserve as soon as possible. However, in the meantime and until a full time instructor can be employed we would recommend the temporary employment of Mr. Weller to commence duties at the earliest possible moment.

R.F. Ragan,
Superintendent,
Blood Indian Reserve.
